{"uri": "8217565484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:04:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:04:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:02:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/entertainment/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies/article_ec33ac0d-fdc8-561f-a787-9cd869f00c95.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, celebrated tenor in the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "FILE - The Oak Ridge Boys, from left, Joe Bonsall, Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban appear at the Grammy Awards with their their award for Country Performance by a duo or group in Los Angeles, Calif., Feb. 24, 1982. Bonsall died on Tuesday, July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis in Hendersonville, Tenn. He was 76.\n\nJoe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.", "source": {"uri": "idahostatejournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Idaho State Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217734856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:16:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:16:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:06:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-220706739.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, The Oak Ridge Boys country tenor, dies at 76 from complications of ALS", "body": "July 9 (UPI) -- Joe Bonsall, who spent more than five decades performing tenor with the country vocal quartet The Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of ALS at the age of 76.\n\n\"Joseph Bonsall of Hendersonville, Tenn., passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis,\" his family wrote in a statement on his website Tuesday, announcing his death.\n\n\"As a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame,\" his family added.\n\nBonsall's death on Tuesday comes six months after he announced his retirement earlier this year from The Oak Ridge Boys during their Farewell Tour.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall wrote Jan. 3, in a post on X.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all The Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" Bonsall added. \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall, who sang with The Faith Four and The Keystone Quartet in the 1960s, joined The Oak Ridge Boys as a tenor in 1973. He and his country singing partners William Lee Golden, Duane Allen and Richard Sterban sold more than 41 million albums.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys won five Grammy Awards and produced more than 30 top-five country hits, including \"Bobbie Sue,\" \"American Made,\" \"Leaving Louisiana in the Broad Daylight,\" and \"Elvira.\"\n\nBonsall was also the author of 11 books, including On the Road with The Oak Ridge Boys and his memoir I See Myself, which is scheduled for release in November.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies,\" his family said Tuesday. \"But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nIn 2018, Bonsall and The Oak Ridge Boys sang \"Amazing Grace\" at the funeral for President George H.W. Bush, after making a promise to the former president three decades earlier.\n\n\"The vice president comes tearing across the White House lawn,\" Bonsall told CNN as he recounted the 1983 encounter.\n\n\"Here comes George Bush running towards us, saying, 'I can't make it tonight, but I'm a huge country fan, I'm a big Oak fan. Will you sing some of your songs?'\" Bonsall recounted.\n\n\"He started listing album cuts, so he wasn't kidding,\" Bonsall said. \"We were just blown away that the vice president knew our music.\"\n\nWhile on tour in 2018, the group made a quick detour to play one last time for the former president at his funeral.\n\n\"We've been carrying a suit on our tour bus for a couple of months and wondering,\" Bonsall said. \"By hook or by crook, we were going to be there for him.\"\n\nWhile no funeral is planned for Bonsall, his family has requested donations be made to The ALS Association and the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nOn Tuesday, reaction to Bonsall's death began pouring in from country singers including Blake Shelton, who said \"We all lost a special person today,\" and Lee Greenwood, who called Bonsall \"the high voice with The Oak Ridge Boys who I toured with almost every year of my career.\"\n\n\"My family sends prayers to the Bonsall Family and The Oak Ridge Boys,\" Greenwood added. \"We will miss you, Joe!", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217310034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:22:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:22:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:21:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://popculture.com/country-music/news/the-oak-ridge-boys-singer-joe-bonsall-dead-at-76/", "title": "The Oak Ridge Boys Singer Joe Bonsall Dead at 76", "body": "Singer Joe Bonsall, a longtime member of The Oak Ridge Boys, has died. He was 76. In a press release, the legendary country and gospel group stated that Bonsall \"passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.\" His family is requesting privacy at this time.\n\nFirst joining The Oak Ridge Boys in 1973, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame. Bonsall retired from touring in 2023, due to multiple health issues, including battling a \"slow onset\" of a neuromuscular disease, per The Hill.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by The Oak Ridge Boys (@theoakridgeboys)\n\nIn addition to his illustrious music career, Bonsall is also the author of 11 books. His latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, will be released in November. \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies,\" stated a joint message from the surviving members of The Oak Ridge Boys. \"But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "popculture.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-416669229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:18:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:18:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:00:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://triblive.com/aande/celebrity-news/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-oak-ridge-boys-dies-at-76/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, celebrated tenor in the country and gospel group Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.", "source": {"uri": "triblive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TribLIVE"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@triblive.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-07-416631542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:22:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:22:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://m.arcamax.com/entertainment/entertainmenttoday/s-3322204", "title": "Joe Bonsall, longtime tenor in country and gospel quartet the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, a singer who dedicated more than 50 years to the Grammy winning country and gospel quartet the Oak Ridge Boys, has died. He was 76.\n\nThe tenor's website announced in a statement that Bonsall died Tuesday from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a neurodegenerative disease also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease. In January, Bonsall said he was battling a neuromuscular disorder that prompted his retirement from the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\n\"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said in a January statement on X. \"It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nHe added at the time: \"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys spread news of Bonsall's death online, sharing a photo of the singer and the statement on the group's various soci al media platforms\n\nBonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys, known for hits including \"Elvira\" and \"Bobbie Sue,\" 30 years after its founding in 1943. He became a member after a gig with the Keystones and was a mainstay as the group achieved mainstream success throughout the '70s and '80s. The Tennessee group gained popularity in gospel circles and touted Johnny Cash, Ray Charles, Brenda Lee and Paul Simon among its collaborators.\n\nThe group earned its first Grammy Award in the gospel performance category in 1971. The Oak Ridge Boys would go on to win four additional Grammys, including one for \"Elvira\" in 1982. The group has a total of 23 Grammy nominations.\n\n\"We're the act that won't go away,\" Bonsall told The Times in 1996 after a performance in Glendale, California. \"We're not kids anymore, but we're out there rockin'.\"\n\nBonsall, a member of the Grand Ole Opry, was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame, according to his website.\n\nThe musician was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015, the same year the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry in the United States. In response to the decision, Bonsall declared, \"It's a sad day for those that care about spirituality and principles based on the Bible,\" and swiftly faced backlash.\n\nIn the years before his death, Bonsall toured seemingly nonstop with the Oak Ridge Boys, save for their hiatus amid the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.\n\nBefore announcing his retirement this year, Bonsall had revealed in 2022 that he had battled pulmonary embolisms, telling fans at the time, \"I could've easily died last weekend.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys launched their American Made Farewell Tour in September 2023, and singer-songwriter Ben James took over for Bonsall amid his retirement.\n\nBefore his death, Bonsall authored 11 books, including his upcoming memoir \"I See Myself,\" which is set to publish in November. Music, family and faith were central to Bonsall, his website said.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo,\" the statement added. \"He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall was born May 18, 1948, in Philadelphia. He is survived by wife Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nThe family will not host a funeral, at Bonsall's request. Supporters can donate to the ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\n-- -- --\n\n(Former L.A. Times staff writer Jonah Valdez contributed to this report.)", "source": {"uri": "m.arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "m.arcamax.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "arcamax_publishing@m.arcamax.com", {"uri": "2024-07-416577314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:12:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:12:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:58:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/joe-bonsall-longtime-tenor-country-175857650.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, longtime tenor in country and gospel quartet the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, a singer who dedicated more than 50 years to the Grammy-winning country and gospel quartet the Oak Ridge Boys, has died. He was 76.\n\nThe tenor's website announced in a statement that Bonsall died Tuesday from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a neurodegenerative disease also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease. In January, Bonsall said he was battling a neuromuscular disorder that prompted his retirement from the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\n\"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said in a January statement on X. \"It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nHe added at the time: \"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nRead more: Oak Ridge Boys singer retires from the road after 50 years due to neuromuscular disorder\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys spread news of Bonsall's death online, sharing a photo of the singer and the statement on the group's various social media platforms\n\nBonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys, known for hits including \"Elvira\" and \"Bobbie Sue,\" 30 years after its founding in 1943. He became a member after a gig with the Keystones and was a mainstay as the group achieved mainstream success throughout the '70s and '80s. The Tennessee group gained popularity in gospel circles and touted Johnny Cash, Ray Charles, Brenda Lee and Paul Simon among its collaborators.\n\nThe group earned its first Grammy Award in the gospel performance category in 1971. The Oak Ridge Boys would go on to win four additional Grammys, including one for \"Elvira\" in 1982. The group has a total of 23 Grammy nominations.\n\n\"We're the act that won't go away,\" Bonsall told The Times in 1996 after a performance in Glendale. \"We're not kids anymore, but we're out there rockin'.\"\n\nRead more: Dickey Betts, guitarist and founding member of the Allman Brothers Band, dies 80\n\nBonsall, a member of the Grand Ole Opry, was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame, according to his website.\n\nThe musician was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015, the same year the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry in the United States. In response to the decision, Bonsall declared, \"It's a sad day for those that care about spirituality and principles based on the Bible,\" and swiftly faced backlash.\n\nIn the years before his death, Bonsall toured seemingly nonstop with the Oak Ridge Boys, save for their hiatus amid the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.\n\nBefore announcing his retirement this year, Bonsall had revealed in 2022 that he had battled pulmonary embolisms, telling fans at the time, \"I could've easily died last weekend.\"\n\nRead more: Mark Ross, aka Brother Marquis of Miami hip-hop group 2 Live Crew, dead at 58\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys launched their American Made Farewell Tour in September 2023, and singer-songwriter Ben James took over for Bonsall amid his retirement.\n\nBefore his death, Bonsall authored 11 books, including his upcoming memoir \"I See Myself,\" which is set to publish in November. Music, family and faith were central to Bonsall, his website said.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo,\" the statement added. \"He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall was born May 18, 1948, in Philadelphia. He is survived by wife Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nThe family will not host a funeral, at Bonsall's request. Supporters can donate to the ALS Assn. or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nFormer Times staff writer Jonah Valdez contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "8217704917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:30:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:30:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:29:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.mercurynews.com/2024/07/09/joe-bonsall-dies-at-76-beloved-singer-in-country-group-the-oak-ridge-boys/", "title": "Joe Bonsall dies at 76; beloved singer in country group the Oak Ridge Boys", "body": "The tenor died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis\n\nBy Maria Sherman and Kaitlyn Huamani | Associated Press\n\nJoe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.", "source": {"uri": "mercurynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "San Jose Mercury News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9718643", "eventUri": "eng-9718643", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3647058823529412, "wgt": 230, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8218813542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:41:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:41:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:41:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://journalnow.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_eec5c4bd-1172-5fba-afe2-09d8ea9ba005.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or {"uri": "8218832905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:54:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:54:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:53:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_0bfc899f-7209-5efc-80f7-ff2c7bc6dcb8.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say 8-year-old boy dies after Wednesday night crash on I-74 Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop LaSalle County man dies in illegal fireworks incident Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Flick Fact: The $800M ex-farm girl from Stanford and Olympia High? McLean County man detained on cocaine sales charges Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Behind the Pritzker administration's quest to signal Illinois is 'open for business' Funerals pending for July 4 Funerals pending for July 5 Illinois State basketball turns to Lieb, Walker for inside production\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I {"uri": "8218806273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:37:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:37:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:36:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_010ee8b6-63be-5346-ba68-96a6b9034f97.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0 * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to {"uri": "8217952490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:49:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:49:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:49:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.cleveland.com/music/2024/07/longtime-member-of-hugely-popular-country-gospel-group-dies-at-age-76.html", "title": "Longtime member of hugely popular country-gospel group dies at age 76", "body": "HENDERSONVILLE, Tennessee -- Joe Bonsall, who was a member of the country-gospel group The Oak Ridge Boys for 50 years, died Tuesday at the age of 76.\n\nBonsall, a tenor and Grammy winner with the group, died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement posted online.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement says. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nThe news of his death brought tributes from other members of the Oak Ridge Boys and from musical artists.\n\n\"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled,\" Duane Allen, a member of The Oak Ridge Boys, said in a statement. \"Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love, and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song, and book.\"\n\n\"Joe Bonsall was one of the kindest people I ever met,\" country star Trace Adkins said in a post on social media. \"He was a rock star, and he was a wonderful human being. RIP Joe.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\nBonsall also is the author of 11 books, with the latest, a memoir titled \"I See Myself,\" set to be released in November.\n\nHe was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame. He also was a member of the Grand Ole Opry.\n\n\"Every single one of us at the Grand Ole Opry absolutely loved Joe Bonsall,\" said Dan Rogers, senior VP/executive producer of the Grand Ole Opry, in a statement. \"Safe travels, buddy. You are so loved.\"\n\n\"For fifty years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" said Hall of Fame CEO Kyle Young in a post on social media. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance, and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. The family's statement says there will be no funeral upon Bonsall's request and instead asks that people make donations to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Here's where the fireworks are this July 4 in South Jersey Scientists know rising seas will one day swallow this Jersey Shore climate research center Rents are up, but vacationers are still heading to the Jersey Shore Last of brothers who started Starn's ShopRite dies at age 89 Route 30 reopened in both directions following repairs to Absecon Drawbridge Cove Beach at capacity; no additional cars allowed Some Stanley Holmes Village residents say they will fight to keep their apartments, others ready to go Greg Goodwin, influential Absegami coach, dies at 63 17-year-old dies in fatal Dennis Township crash Former site for Sister Jean's, 'Nucky' Johnson wedding to be demolished to make way for cannabis business Atlantic City woman involved in hit-and-run while kids in car Wharton State Forest fire up to 1,200 acres, 40% contained Ousted Atlantic City school board member sues, alleging retaliation, racial discrimination Cape May fishing case has national impact Mays Landing man charged in fatal stabbing\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. "https://myfox8.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/17/2024/07/JoeBonsall_2024_byJonMir_lrg-e1720540835151.jpg?strip=1&w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9718643", "eventUri": "eng-9718643", {"uri": "2024-07-416626607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:15:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:15:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:24:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies/article_c299860b-9e9d-5d9d-bc20-a86b27d690a1.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, celebrated tenor in the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research Adds Brandon Hall as New EVP of Operations\n\nUnited Filmmakers Announces an Exciting Financing Opportunity for Independent Filmmakers\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "kaitlyn_huamani@kulr8.com", "name": "Kaitlyn Huamani", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8218858005", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:10:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:10:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:09:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://missoulian.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_408b0745-5424-5865-a6b7-ef67826f31b5.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Couple sues Community Medical Center, pediatric surgeon for 'negligent conduct' Shootout in Yellowstone Park leaves one man dead, ranger wounded Missoula Redevelopment Agency eyes big projects on the horizon Missoula business owner issued sexual assault citation UPDATED: New wildfire starts Sunday in upper Miller Creek Sen. Tester speaks out on President Biden's debate performance Missoula city council member insinuates 'pay to play' scheme, draws sharp rebukes A birthday and a warning Glacier National Park reports 2 Saturday drownings University of Montana researcher admits to federal fraud Human remains found in Missoula County 'Reality check': Pyramid runs final log through sawmill Person caught on camera tearing down another Pride flag from Missoula business Mark Zuckerberg surfs while drinking beer, holding flag. Rival Elon Musk can't resist snark Mountain Line: River floating drop-off at Sha-Ron available\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that
