{"uri": "8218359739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:06:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:06:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:05:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/jul/10/longtime-oak-ridge-boys-tenor-joe-bonsall-dies-at/", "title": "Longtime Oak Ridge Boys tenor Joe Bonsall dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tenn., Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song ,\"Elvira,\" 1982's \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\"\n\n\"Elvira\" marked a crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on the social media platorm X, then Twitter, he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.", "source": {"uri": "arkansasonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Twitter"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/In_Memoriam", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/In Memoriam", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Relationships/Romance", "label": "dmoz/Society/Relationships/Romance", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 99}], "image": "https://wehco.media.clients.ellingtoncms.com/imports/adg/photos/207666234_2AJoeBonsall0710_t600.jpg?4326734cdb8e39baa3579048ef63ad7b451e7676", "originalArticle": {"uri": "8218828279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:51:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:51:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:50:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_c1110b54-ca16-54cb-8c2f-d4b0875b52eb.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man shot outside bar in downtown Waterloo Ag expert: Deere prepares for future losses due to downturned ag economy Woman dead in single-vehicle accident John Deere closes on land for 1.2 million-square-foot Indiana warehouse Woman identified in fatal crash Waterloo man arrested after alleged assault at Sunnyside County Club Woman arrested for assaulting multiple people, punching officer, ramming property in Waterloo Restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi John Eveland: Waterloo businessman makes lasting impact in Cedar Valley community Firecracker Fourth of July celebrations planned throughout Cedar Valley Walnut Ridge Church to move to Tower Park Drive, future uncertain for private school space Bond remains same in pre-teen sex sting in Evansdale Student sentenced to probation in University of Northern Iowa Dance Marathon theft College Football: Cedar Falls OL, second Tiger commits to Northern Iowa football program Man arrested for skate park gun threats\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Long awaited 2nd location of Rollies Mexican Patio coming to Tucson's west side Where to see the fireworks tonight in Tucson Santa Catalina forest ranger under investigation amid claims of hostile behavior A local rescue just opened a new cat lounge in Tucson \ud83d\udc08 100 fun events happening in Tucson this July 2024 \ud83e\udeb4\ud83c\udfa8 Two Democrats vie in primary for Pima County treasurer nomination These Tucson-area Albertsons, Safeway stores cold be sold in proposed merger Tornado touches down in Tucson, officials confirm 'Absolutely breathtaking': America's first official 'quiet trail' sits in the Nebraska Sandhills Tucson's 112 breaks daily heat record Motorcyclist killed in crash near Tucson UA Global Campus pays 'practically nothing' to faculty, think tank says Where to watch fireworks in Tucson this Fourth of July 9 secret menus at Tucson restaurants and food trucks \ud83d\udc40 Take your pick from these Tucson-area Fourth of July fireworks shows\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nSubscribe to stay connected to Tucson. {"uri": "2024-07-416601223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:43:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:43:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T14:24:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/tennessee/articles/2024-07-09/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies-at-76", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Celebrated Tenor in the Country and Gospel Group the Oak Ridge Boys, Dies at 76", "body": "Bonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. His death comes days after the passing of Rusty Golden, fellow Oak Ridge member William Lee Golden's son at the age of 65.\n\nHis death was announced via a release through his publicist on social media that stated: \"Bonsall, of Hendersonville, Tennessee passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.\"\n\n\"He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\"\n\nBlake, 48, who had performed with The Oak Ridge Boys in the past, took to his Instagram with a photograph from one of their shows and shared a heartfelt tribute to his \"friend\" Bonsall.\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing,\" he penned. \"I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life.\"\n\nHe continued: \"He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and his @theoakridgeboys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nMORE: Heartbroken Kate Winslet leads tributes to Titanic producer Jon Landau: 'I can't believe he's gone'\n\nThe official statement announcing Bonsall's death continues: \"As a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\"\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nMORE: Jerry West, basketball legend on NBA logo, dead at 86\n\nIt added that at his request, there will not be a funeral. \"In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\" His family has requested privacy.\n\nBonsall, who was the tenor for the vocal group, announced in January that he would be retiring from touring with a statement that read: \"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder.\"\n\nMORE: Tributes pour in as Law and Order star Tony Lo Bianco dies aged 87\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\n\"There is a young man named Ben James singing for me out there, and he needs your love and encouragement ... his sound is different than mine, but he brings a ton of talent to the table! The Oak Ridge Boys will finish the Farewell Tour without me, but rest assured, I am good with all of it!\"", "source": {"uri": "hellomagazine.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "HELLO!"}, "authors": {"uri": "8218810455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:40:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:40:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:39:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://richmond.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_07599ab3-0279-5590-bf92-5502c4aacc55.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster Richmond-area Fourth of July guide: Where to catch the fireworks New Richmond ballpark now has general contractors on the team 9-year-old boy drowns at Pony Pasture With new ballpark, might Triple-A baseball return to RVA? Crash on Pocahontas Parkway in Henrico kills Chesterfield woman CEO of Virginia's technology authority resigns 18-year-old from Ohio drowns in Nags Head Richmond radio personality Kat Simons dies at 63 As farmers age out, future of the mythic Hanover tomato is uncertain ACLU sues Hanover Public Schools on behalf of 11-year-old trans tennis player The butterfly effect: Crozet teenager Thomas Heilman's journey to 2024 Paris Olympics What to know about Thursday's Independence Day event at the Virginia State Capitol Bar association cancels Senate debate without commitment from Cao UPDATE: Colorado teen identified as person who died at Smith Mountain Lake on Thursday\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "richmond.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Richmond Times-Dispatch"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The degenerative nervous system disease can affect nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.\n\nBonsall announced on social media about six months ago that he was leaving the group.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nBonsall noted that \"it has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\n\"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying,\" he added.\n\nBonsall explained at the time that Ben James is singing in the group in his stead, writing that \"his sound is different than mine but he brings a ton of talent to the table!\"\n\nJoe Bonsall, Duane Allen, William Lee Golden, and Richard Sterban of The Oak Ridge Boys onstage during in 2015.\n\nRick Diamond/Getty Images\n\n\"The @oakridgeboys will finish the Farewell Tour without me but rest assured I am good with all of it!\" he concluded. \"God's Got It!!!\"\n\nThe country and gospel quartet, originally founded in 1943 out ot Tennessee, are known for songs including \"Elvira\" and \"American Made.\" Bonsall joined the group in 1973.\n\nDuring his long career, Bonsall became a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nHe was also the author of 11 books, including a memoir titled, \"I See Myself: Musings and Memories of a Blessed Life,\" which is set to be published in November.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the announcement from his management reads. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance, and Grey, and a sister, Nancy.\n\nAt his request, there will be no funeral and in lieu of flowers donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the {"uri": "8218795598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:31:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:31:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:31:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_cccbf100-77a7-576e-b4c2-abb587f0928f.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... McCook Lake Association president: 'There's really no compensation' for flood losses Where to go for firework displays in Siouxland Belly up to the bar-cade: Warp Zone brings bar and arcade combo to downtown Sioux City Panel looks to release more water from Okoboji lakes without hurting flood-stricken Spencer, Cherokee Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 8, 2024 Saturday in the Park continues to bring in big name acts without charging admission REVIEW: Bleachers teach plenty at Saturday in the Park 1 killed, 1 hurt in crash near Lake Park McCook Lake residents seek answers for flood recovery North Sioux City updates residents on flood recovery Iowa legislator J.D. Scholten earns win in last-minute start for Sioux City Explorers Ex-Plymouth County deputy to plead guilty of stealing drugs Issues continue to plague Woodbury County jail project, sheriff shares concerns Body of missing 17-year-old who jumped into Platte River to save girl found, authorities say Saturday in the Park 2024 kicks-off with high spirits\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! {"uri": "8218848517", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:04:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:04:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:04:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://statesville.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_e6b8361a-1485-5103-90cc-71912f49d315.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Former Statesville Christian coach sentenced on two counts of assaulting female Iredell sisters arrested on drug charges after traffic stop Fayetteville man charged in fatal Iredell County wreck Statesville man critically injured in Friday shooting After a year in the spotlight, Taylor Loyd looks beyond Miss North Carolina Sheriff: Statesville mother charged after toddler treated for an overdose Six charged in Alexander County shooting, including two juveniles Iredell chase ends with crash; one reported dead Man arrested in Statesville sex offense investigation after standoff in Rowan County Olin teen charged with possessing stolen firearm Iredell EMS deputy director talks about his termination. Appeal set for July 10 Statesville's Nate Neely showcases his hand-carved duck decoys Toddler killed by truck at Steel Creek campground north of Morganton Corey Thompson named next head men's basketball coach at Winston-Salem State Burkemont Mountain in Morganton ablaze with 30-acre wildfire\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/statesville.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/6b/e6b8361a-1485-5103-90cc-71912f49d315/668df933115f0.preview.jpg?crop=1724%2C905%2C0%2C141&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9718643", "eventUri": "eng-9718643", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-10", "textStart": 1825, "textEnd": 1832}], "sentiment": -0.02745098039215688, "wgt": 223, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8218824557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:49:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:49:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:48:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://qctimes.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_29616d33-946a-5245-be6f-62f349cdafdd.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... An early look at Davenport's plans for Main Street Landing Chicago company buys apartment buildings in Davenport, Moline Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Shelly's Sweet Sensations, Crawford Brew Works and more Agriculture expert: Deere prepares for future losses due to declining ag economy Driver of vehicle in LeClaire crash identified John Deere closes on land for 1.2 million-square-foot warehouse in Indiana Moline woman gave report of missing mail to postal worker accused of stealing mail Police identify woman killed by crash Monday afternoon northwest of Davenport Matt Moody managed the Village Theater and touched many lives Review: Lainey Wilson sings in the rain Sunday at the John Deere Classic 7 Quad Cities restaurants that opened in June Review: Counting Crows at the John Deere Classic 'Concerts on the Course' Brazilian bomber Bolkema excelling Davenport North Registered sex offender accused of inappropriately touching girl Sarah Goodwin says her husband's life was 'swirling out of control' before he was killed\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or {"uri": "2024-07-416683164", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:40:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:40:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:34:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://eu.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2024/07/09/oak-ridge-boys-members-joe-bonsall-left-big-impact-in-50-year-run/74339814007/", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys mourn death of Joe Bonsall. What to know about the 50-year member of the long-running vocal group.", "body": "Celebrating the life and legacy of Joe Bonsall, the longtime tenor vocalist of the Oak Ridge Boys, who recently passed away at 76 due to ALS complications.\n\nOn Tuesday, Oak Ridge Boys member Joe Bonsall died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis at 76 years old. In the midst of the tenor vocalist's passing, his longtime band members mourned his loss.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boy's posted on Instagram, notifying their fans of Bonsall's death.\n\nThe caption said, \"As a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\"\n\nThe post said that Joseph S. Bonsall leaves behind his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and sister, Nancy.\n\nAt this time, the family is requesting privacy.\n\n\"Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November,\" the caption continued.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nThe band members said that at the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral.\n\nInstead of flowers, they ask fans to donate to the ALS Association or Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nBonsall was a singer, author and father who lived in Hendersonville, TN.\n\nA Philadelphia native, Bonsall became the 30th of 35 total performers to join the Oak Ridge Boys. Bonsall joined the group in 1973 and was a 50-year member of the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\nJoe Bonsall announced his retirement from the group in December 2023.\n\nIn a press release, he said, \"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road.\"\n\n\"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" he continued.\n\n\"I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying. The Oak Ridge Boys will finish the Farewell Tour without me, but rest assured, I am good with all of it! God's Got It!!!\"\n\nHe was replaced by singer Ben James upon his retirement.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys formed in 1943 in Oak Ridge, Tennessee.\n\nThey grew to popularity in the '50s as Southern gospel music gained momentum. Later, they shifted to country music.\n\nOver the years, they've had approximately 35 members come and go, both as short-term fill-ins and long-term band members.\n\nThe current Oak Ridge Boys members are baritone William Lee Golden, lead vocalist Duane Allen, bass singer Richard Sterban, and Ben James, who replaced Joe Bonsall.\n\nGolden joined in 1965, Allen in 1966, Bonsall in 1973 and Sterban in 1972.\n\nWho were the past Oak Ridge Boys members?\n\nThe quartet has had many singers join them onstage in since '43, and the current three members are only a small fraction of the long list of Oak Ridge Boys.\n\nThe quartet formed in 1943 as a group called Wally Fowler and the Georgia Clodhoppers. They began recording music in 1947.\n\nThe original quartet was comprised of Wally Fowler, Lon \"Deacon\" Freeman, Curly Kinsey and Johnny New.\n\nThe quartet shifted to calling themselves the Oak Ridge Quartet and in '62, started calling themselves the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\n'Elvira' and the Oak Ridge Boys' biggest hits, accolades\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys are known for songs \"Elvira,\" \"Bobbie Sue,\" \"American Made\" \"Y'all Come Back Saloon\" and \"Leaving Louisiana In The Broad Daylight.\"\n\nThe band was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015 and has won three Grammy Awards, several Dove Awards, Academy of Country Music Awards and Country Music Association Awards.", "source": {"uri": "tennessean.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tennessean"}, "authors": [],
