{"uri": "8218810145", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:39:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:39:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:39:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_64ce2859-d935-587d-8105-7dd971762c9c.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago Toddler killed by truck at Steel Creek campground north of Morganton Golden Hour Charcuterie opens in Marion's Depot District 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report Nebo woman charged with break-in McDowell Little League crowns two champions; league to host a baseball state tournament Burkemont Mountain in Morganton ablaze with 30-acre wildfire When are the 4th of July fireworks, parades in McDowell County? McDowell calendar: Independence Day parades set for today Mission Hospital McDowell's new CEO planning to get to know the community Marion's Spillway Bridge & Co. set to reopen under new owners Man found dead near Lake James in McDowell County\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or {"uri": "8218799623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:33:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:33:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:33:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_78e05601-dce8-508f-9834-0cd544bd4f69.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Batter and Brew hits the streets in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Downtown Holiday Inn converting to boutique hotel in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Crumbl Cookies to begin construction in late summer in Onalaska UPDATE: Skyrockers firework show postponed; more closures due to rain and flooding Local talent shines in first-ever Riverfest Idol karaoke tournament Dane County judge strikes down part of Act 10 One injured in three vehicle crash near Arcadia Viroqua's fireworks show postponed due to inclement weather Galesville man charged with eluding police and stealing vehicle in Onalaska Onalaska man charged with felony for pointing gun at woman's head during argument Two spills of chemical firefighting foam occurred at La Crosse Regional Airport earlier this year, reports say Vernon County gears up for Independence Day celebrations Tellurian awarded $35,000 from Mayo Health Spring boys all-conference teams: Complete Coulee Region listing Alaska man faces felony charges for assault in Winona that led to shelter-in-place order\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I {"uri": "8217823322", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:07:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:07:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:06:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2781336/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, famed tenor of country and gospel group Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76 - ExBulletin", "body": "Bonsall died from complications of a neuromuscular disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, according to a statement from his family's representatives.\n\nJoe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play the banjo. He loved to work on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\n\nA Philadelphia native and Hendersonville, Tennessee resident, Bonsall left his gospel group, the Keystones, in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the group through its golden era in the '80s and beyond, which included its 1981 hit \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" Elvira marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections needed to control muscles for movements such as walking, speaking, and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of diagnosis. The disease is known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last through 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too physically demanding for him after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who played with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have retired from the road. It has become too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years and I am grateful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, the band, the team and the staff for the constant love and support they have shown me throughout this time. I will never forget, and for those of you who have constantly supported me in prayer, I thank you and ask that you continue to pray.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on Xformerly Twitter, that he could have easily died after suffering a pulmonary embolism.\n\nHer memoir, I See Myself, will be published posthumously in November. It is her 11th book, a collection that includes the four-part children's series, The Molly Books.\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of The Grand Ole OpryHe has been inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and The Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nFor 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the driving force behind the Oak Ridge Boys. He was as exciting an entertainer as any who ever graced the gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a burst of energy, immediately inspiring audiences to come and relax. He certainly lightened our worries every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich sharing a memory on X\"Country music mourns today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a true friend, someone I admired not only as an artist, but as a man. He left behind an incredible legacy of music and countless testaments to his kindness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt Also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, Joe had an incredible talent and a wonderful personality and he will be terribly missed by all who knew him.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great-grandsons, Chance and Grey.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8218816511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:43:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:43:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:43:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://scnow.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_94669a48-e2dd-53f8-9f83-46b6648f9c11.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "FILE - Joe Bonsall of The Oak Ridge Boys performs at the CMA Music Festival in Nashville, Tenn., on June 12, 2015. Bonsall died on Tuesday, July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis in Hendersonville, Tenn. He was 76.\n\nJimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hartsville woman dies in July 4 Florence County crash Three people shot Saturday outside Florence Waffle House One person killed in Florence West Evans Street shooting Florence's Mack Hines died July 4, helped many in need Darlington company, DHEC target of 1,4-dioxane litigation City of Florence launches customer service chatbot Cypress Miss SC USA contestant aims to help young moms South Florence's Vereen signs with CFL's Alouettes Florence celebrates July 4 with second annual Freedom 5k SPORTS ROUNDUP: Florence Junior Legion caps perfect regular season CPL NOTEBOOK: Injured Oakley joins Flamingos' coaching staff Darlington County school board discusses cell phone ban Butler Heritage Week culminates with annual parade Lake View's Leonard hosts annual free youth football camp At MUSC kids eat free in July to address food insecurity\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or {"uri": "8217378384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:14:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:14:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:13:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/joe-bonsall-longtime-member-oak-170500291.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dies of ALS Complications at 76", "body": "The country singer announced his retirement from touring with his band in January amid a years-long battle with the neurological disorder\n\nJoe Bonsall, Country Music Hall of Famer and longtime member of the iconic Oak Ridge Boys, has died. He was 76.\n\nAccording to a press release shared with PEOPLE, the singer died on Tuesday, July 9, from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). He's survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey and a sister, Nancy. The family requests privacy at this time.\n\nPer Bonsall's request, a funeral will not be held for him, but donations can be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nRelated: The Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall Is Retiring from Touring Due to Neuromuscular Disorder: 'I Will Never Forget' (Exclusive)\n\nThe death of Bonsall (born Joseph S. Bonsall Jr.) comes months after the musician announced his retirement from touring with The Oak Ridge Boys. The tenor singer told PEOPLE that he was stepping back to prioritize his health amid a years-long battle, though he kept his exact diagnosis private at the time.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said in January. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe musician added, \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall, born and raised in Philadelphia, had been a member of The Oak Ridge Boys for over 50 years before his death. According to the band's website, he began singing around age 4 and later \"fell in love with Southern Gospel music harmony\" in his mid-teens.\n\nHe joined the legendary group in 1973 before they emerged onto the country music scene, where they eventually spawned dozens of hits (including 1984's \"American Made\") and a host of accolades that landed them -- including Bonsall -- in the prestigious Grand Ole Opry, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame. Bonsall was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame back in 1994.\n\nIn addition to being a mainstay in one of country music's leading bands, Bonsall also achieved feats outside of music, like writing 11 books, per the press release -- including an upcoming memoir titled I See Myself, which will be released in November.\n\nPrior to his retirement, the singer-songwriter's band announced a celebratory farewell tour to commemorate their 50th anniversary. \"We are doing a farewell tour because we owe it to our fans to say goodbye,\" William Lee Golden said in a press release. \"They have always been there for us through the good times and the bad. I will always be thankful to every person who came out to a show, bought a T-shirt, played our music, and overall, loved us enough to spend their hard-earned money whenever they could. This tour is for you!\"\n\nRelated: Rusty Golden, Son of the Oak Ridge Boys' William Lee Golden, Dies at 65: 'A Wonderful Son'\n\nIn his own statement, Bonsall told PEOPLE, \"You could have never convinced that 25-year-old Joe Bonsall in 1973 that in 50 years the four of us would still be singing together and still loving every second of it.\"\n\n\"Our mantra has always been LET'S SING... it still is!\" he concluded. \"We have had our share of challenges over all these decades, but we have always persevered as men who have each always cared about doing things right and God has blessed us for it.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nOn January 3, 2024, Bonsall, born Joseph S. Bonsall Jr., announced his retirement from The Oak Ridge Boys ongoing Farewell Tour due to increasing health issues and immobility.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Joe shared in a statement on the social platform X.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" he continued. \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall joined The Oak Ridge Boys in 1973, singing tenor. The group's five-decade-plus career produced over 30 top-five country hits, nearly half of which were chart-toppers, including \"Leaving Louisiana in the Broad Daylight,\" \"Bobbie Sue,\" \"American Made,\" and their signature song, 1981's RIAA-certified double-platinum hit \"Elvira.\"\n\nThe group, also comprised of Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban, won five Grammy Awards and {"uri": "8218805713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:37:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:37:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:36:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_c82bbea7-5491-5da7-8597-cac0edfbc615.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Passenger arrested after flight makes unscheduled stop at Buffalo airport Lake Erie temp reaches an 'unprecedented' early high in Buffalo. A snowy winter could follow - or not Sabres trade top prospect Matt Savoie to Oilers for Ryan McLeod, Tyler Tullio Stop and look: How the new Bills stadium is already drawing in spectators Bills quarterback Mitch Trubisky finds his way back home Pregnant in her sophomore year, Bennett High School graduate finds self-worth - with plenty of help Do the Sabres need a goal-scorer after landing Ryan McLeod to center the third line? Miranda tries - again - to put a Tim Hortons in Orchard Park Bills training camp questions: Which veterans could be on roster bubble? Savannah Bananas bring stilts, shimmies and sing-alongs to rock Sahlen Field Erie County real estate transactions Inside the NHL: Jason Zucker is betting on himself to bring Sabres some offense July Fourth festivities in Western New York: Fireworks, music and food Buffalo State has dismissed its women's wrestling staff before its inaugural season. Here's what we know Fear of assassinations, witness retaliation sparks dispute over evidence in Gerace, Outlaws Motorcycle Club case\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that {"uri": "8217475755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:36:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:36:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.local3news.com/regional-national/joe-bonsall-a-50-year-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76/article_923d44b8-7800-51d5-a365-bdedd7e48155.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, a 50-year member of The Oak Ridge Boys, dead at 76", "body": "(CNN) -- Joe Bonsall, who left the legendary singing group The Oak Ridge Boys after 50 years in January due to a neuromuscular disorder, has died, his management team announced Tuesday.\n\nHe was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), according to his representatives. The degenerative nervous system disease can affect nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.\n\nBonsall announced on social media about six months ago that he was leaving the group.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nBonsall noted that \"it has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\n\"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying,\" he added.\n\nBonsall explained at the time that Ben James is singing in the group in his stead, writing that \"his sound is different than mine but he brings a ton of talent to the table!\"\n\n\"The @oakridgeboys will finish the Farewell Tour without me but rest assured I am good with all of it!\" he concluded. \"God's Got It!!!\"\n\nThe country and gospel quartet, originally founded in 1943 out ot Tennessee, are known for songs including \"Elvira\" and \"American Made.\" Bonsall joined the group in 1973.\n\nDuring his long career, Bonsall became a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nHe was also the author of 11 books, including a memoir titled, \"I See Myself: Musings and Memories of a Blessed Life,\" which is set to be published in November.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the announcement from his management reads. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance, and Grey, and a sister, Nancy.\n\nAt his request, there will be no funeral and in lieu of flowers donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "local3news.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local3News.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-416473402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:15:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:15:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:08:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://eu.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2024/07/09/oak-ridge-boys-tenor-vocalist-joe-bonsall-dies-als/74337511007/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Oak Ridge Boys tenor vocalist, dies at 76 from ALS complications", "body": "Country Music Hall of Famer Joe Bonsall, 76, the tenor vocalist of the Oak Ridge Boys, has died from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.\n\nJoe Bonsall, 76, the longtime tenor vocalist of Country Music Hall of Fame inducted and Grand Ole Opry cast member quintet the Oak Ridge Boys, has died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The announcement was made on July 9 by representatives of the artist and the group.\n\nSix months ago, citing the half-decade onset of the previously-mentioned disorder, Bonsall retired from performing on the road with the group after 50 years.\n\nNotably, alongside his Country Music Hall of Fame and Grand Ole Opry membership, Bonsall was an inductee of the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame and Gospel Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer,\" stated Bonsall in January to The Tennessean.\n\nThe Philadelphia native had already been replaced on the road by bluegrass and gospel performer Ben James alongside Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban. In November 2022, James appeared with the quartet who, while performing on the same billing as Dailey & Vincent, brought him onstage to perform their 40-year-old crossover smash \"Elvira.\"\n\n\"Joe handed me the mic and said, 'You've got the next verse. And I'm not sure I will ever get over that moment. 'Elvira' was always on repeat when I was growing up. It's still one of those timeless songs that never grow old,\" offered James in a press statement.\n\nHis Oak Ridge Boys legacy\n\nIn a Dec. 2023 feature, Bonsall described a career as an Oak Ridge Boy member that saw him play over 10,000 concerts in amphitheaters, arenas, stadiums and theaters worldwide as bearing witness to an \"amazing phenomenon\" that \"took on a life of its own\" and \"marks so many unique spaces, stories and times.\"\n\nHe added that the group \"represented the place to be for five decades. Four guys who looked like they shouldn't even know each other have blended harmonies and had a celebrated career.\"\n\nBonsall became an Oak Ridge Boy in Oct. 1973, the 30th of 35 total performers to perform in the group since its 1947 inception.\n\nFor 35 years, The Oak Ridge Boys achieved excellence as a Southern gospel quartet with soulful leanings. However, by the mid-1970s, the group evolved its image in a cosmopolitan direction. Clad in suits from Hollywood fashion designer Harvey Krantz, they began emphasizing \"entertainment\" over preaching to create a mainstream pop-ready, GQ-style country act.\n\nThat spurred a run of 14 Top 10 Billboard Country chart singles, began with 1977's \"Y'all Come Back Saloon\" and included songs like \"Elvira\" and \"American Made\" among many hits.\n\nThat success was marked by moments like 1978's NBC-broadcasted \"World's Largest Indoor Country Music Show,\" where the Oak Ridge Boys appeared at Detroit's Pontiac Silverdome alongside Kenny Rogers, Minnie Pearl, Dottie West and numerous others.\n\n\"We're out there in front of a national audience and 60,000 people running all over the stage singing country music and then we put that big gospel ending on it. It was a feeling like nothing else I'd felt to that point,\" Bonsall recalled to The Tennessean.\n\nBonsall's other notable career interests\n\nOver the past three decades, the vocalist was also the author of 11 books, including \"The Molly Books,\" a four-part children's book series, 2003's \"GI Joe and Lillie,\" about his parents' lives during and after World War II, plus his forthcoming memoir, \"I See Myself,\" which is still scheduled for a Nov. 13, 2024 release.\n\nAbout his memoir, a press statement notes the following:\n\n\"In 'I See Myself,' Joe Bonsall reflects on his life's contrasts and crossroads. From growing up in the inner city of Philadelphia to sitting on the front porch of his log home in rural Tennessee. From hanging with a street gang in his teens to surrendering to Christ at a youth camp. From working as a short order cook to headlining sold-out arenas. And now -- from running across the stage each night to being sidelined by a neuromuscular disorder that has stolen his mobility. However, despite the changing circumstances of Joe's life, two things have not changed. His unwavering faith in God. And his ability to inspire others.\"\n\nBonsall's memoir is currently available for pre-order via Amazon.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "tennessean.com", "dataType": "news", He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Napa's first Fourth of July drone show takes to the sky amid mixed feelings Document at center of Supervisor Ramos' restraining order found in public filings A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. Her life inspired a scholarship. Supervisor Belia Ramos files court documents alleging harassment Judge considers vacating temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Fire hazards and federal subpoenas: Questions continue to swirl around Clover Flat Landfill Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Manslaughter case over cyclist couple killed in Napa moves forward Learn where to celebrate the Fourth of July in the Napa Valley Containment of Toll Fire near Calistoga reaches 50% Bottoms Up!: A converted horse trailer bar for hire in Napa Far Niente Wine Estates to welcome third venture in September St. Helena's V. Sattui Winery sued by former employee alleging wage abuse St. Helena postpones Fourth of July fireworks show due to hot, dry conditions Napa Farmers Market: There's always a place for you at the market\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World Oak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey Jimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or He was 76.\n\nBonsall died on Tuesday, July 9, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), the band announced on its website. He's survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey and a sister, Nancy.\n\nBonsall had announced his retirement from touring at the beginning of the year, while the Oak Ridge Boys continued their farewell tour in his absence.\n\nBonsall was the vocalist of Oak Ridge Boys from 1973 to 2023. Besides charting numerous hits as a member of the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall had a solo chart credit alongside the band Sawyer Brown in their 1986 single \"Out Goin' Cattin'\", on which he was credited as \"Cat Joe Bonsall\".\"\n\nBonsall was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015 as a member of the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\nFor comments and feedback contact: editorial@rttnews.com", "source": {"uri": "8217649750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:28:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:28:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:27:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://americansongwriter.com/the-oak-ridge-boys-share-joe-bonsall-partial-obituary-funeral-details/", "title": "The Oak Ridge Boys Share Partial Obituary, Funeral Details for the Late Joe Bonsall", "body": "This morning (July 9), longtime Oak Rich Boys member Joe Bonsall passed away due to complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). This afternoon, the group took to social media to share some details about Bonsall's life and death as well as news about his funeral arrangements.\n\nVideos by American Songwriter\n\nThe message was short and to the point. However, it did much to shed light on a life that touched so many others. Bonsall wasn't just one of the brightest voices in the Oak Ridge Boys. He was also a family man, a farmer, an author, and a man of faith.\n\n[RELATED: Longtime Oak Ridge Boys Member Joe Bonsall Dead at 76]\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys Share Joe Bonsall's Partial Obituary\n\nAfter noting that Joe Bonsall died due to complications of ALS, the post pointed out that he left several family members behind. \"He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Add, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Beanna, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy,\" it read. \"He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\"\n\nThe partial obituary also highlighted some of Bonsall's professional accomplishments. \"As a 50-year member of the American music group, The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame,\" it noted. However, his accomplishments didn't just lie in the music he made.\n\n\"Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled, I See Myself which releases in November. Joe loved to sing, he loved to read, he loved to write, he loved to play banjo, he loved working on the farm, and he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day,\" the post stated.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral in his honor. In lieu of flowers, he wanted fans, friends, family, and loved ones to make donations to The ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nAt this time, the Bonsall family requests privacy.\n\nFeatured Image by Jason Kempin/Getty Images", "source": {"uri": "americansongwriter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "American Songwriter"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217548847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:47:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:47:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:46:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/09/metro/joe-bonsall-tenor-country-gospel-group-oak-ridge-boys-dies-76/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, tenor in the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76 - The Boston Globe", "body": "\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tenn., Mr. Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue,\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking, and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Mr. Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Mr. Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Mr. Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Mr. Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt posted a tribute on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ALS", {"uri": "8217491292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:50:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:50:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:50:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies/article_7ac57e9f-3110-54ec-ac63-73f74d63c971.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, celebrated tenor in the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say 8-year-old boy dies after Wednesday night crash on I-74 Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen LaSalle County man dies in illegal fireworks incident Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Flick Fact: The $800M ex-farm girl from Stanford and Olympia High? McLean County man detained on cocaine sales charges Aaron Rossi sentenced to 5 years in prison on federal fraud case Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Behind the Pritzker administration's quest to signal Illinois is 'open for business' Crystal Lake man identified in fatal crash near Downs Funerals pending for July 4 Fourth of July celebrations in Bloomington-Normal and beyond \ud83c\udf86\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. He was 76.\n\nThe tenor's website announced in a statement that Bonsall died Tuesday from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a neurodegenerative disease also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease. In January, Bonsall said he was battling a neuromuscular disorder that prompted his retirement from the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\n\"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said in a January statement on X. \"It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nHe added at the time: \"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys spread news of Bonsall's death online, sharing a photo of the singer and the statement on the group's various soci al media platforms\n\nBonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys, known for hits including \"Elvira\" and \"Bobbie Sue,\" 30 years after its founding in 1943. He became a member after a gig with the Keystones and was a mainstay as the group achieved mainstream success throughout the '70s and '80s. The Tennessee group gained popularity in gospel circles and touted Johnny Cash, Ray Charles, Brenda Lee and Paul Simon among its collaborators.\n\nThe group earned its first Grammy Award in the gospel performance category in 1971. The Oak Ridge Boys would go on to win four additional Grammys, including one for \"Elvira\" in 1982. The group has a total of 23 Grammy nominations.\n\n\"We're the act that won't go away,\" Bonsall told The Times in 1996 after a performance in Glendale, California. \"We're not kids anymore, but we're out there rockin'.\"\n\nBonsall, a member of the Grand Ole Opry, was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame, according to his website.\n\nThe musician was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015, the same year the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry in the United States. In response to the decision, Bonsall declared, \"It's a sad day for those that care about spirituality and principles based on the Bible,\" and swiftly faced backlash.\n\n...continued", "source": {"uri": "8217375560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:11:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:11:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:11:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://people.com/oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-dead-age-76-als-complications-8675258", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dies of ALS Complications at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, Country Music Hall of Famer and longtime member of the iconic Oak Ridge Boys, has died. He was 76.\n\nAccording to a press release shared with PEOPLE, the singer died on Tuesday, July 9, from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). He's survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey and a sister, Nancy. The family requests privacy at this time.\n\nPer Bonsall's request, a funeral will not be held for him, but donations can be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nThe death of Bonsall (born Joseph S. Bonsall Jr.) comes months after the musician announced his retirement from touring with The Oak Ridge Boys. The tenor singer told PEOPLE that he was stepping back to prioritize his health amid a years-long battle, though he kept his exact diagnosis private at the time.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said in January. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe musician added, \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall, born and raised in Philadelphia, had been a member of The Oak Ridge Boys for over 50 years before his death. According to the band's website, he began singing around age 4 and later \"fell in love with Southern Gospel music harmony\" in his mid-teens.\n\nHe joined the legendary group in 1973 before they emerged onto the country music scene, where they eventually spawned dozens of hits (including 1984's \"American Made\") and a host of accolades that landed them -- including Bonsall -- in the prestigious Grand Ole Opry, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame. Bonsall was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame back in 1994.\n\nIn addition to being a mainstay in one of country music's leading bands, Bonsall also achieved feats outside of music, like writing 11 books, per the press release -- including an upcoming memoir titled I See Myself, which will be released in November.\n\nPrior to his retirement, the singer-songwriter's band announced a celebratory farewell tour to commemorate their 50th anniversary. \"We are doing a farewell tour because we owe it to our fans to say goodbye,\" William Lee Golden said in a press release. \"They have always been there for us through the good times and the bad. I will always be thankful to every person who came out to a show, bought a T-shirt, played our music, and overall, loved us enough to spend their hard-earned money whenever they could. This tour is for you!\"\n\nIn his own statement, Bonsall told PEOPLE, \"You could have never convinced that 25-year-old Joe Bonsall in 1973 that in 50 years the four of us would still be singing together and still loving every second of it.\"\n\n\"Our mantra has always been LET'S SING... it still is!\" he concluded. \"We have had our share of challenges over all these decades, but we have always persevered as men who have each always cared about doing things right and God has blessed us for it.\"", "source": {"uri": "people.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PEOPLE.com"}, "authors":
