{"uri": "8217407045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:37:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:37:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:36:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/joe-bonsall-dead-at-76-oak-ridge-boys-tenor-passes-due-to-complications-with-amyotrophic-lateral-sclerosis/", "title": "Joe Bonsall dead at 76: Oak Ridge Boys tenor passes due to complications with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis", "body": "Joe Bonsall, a member of the country and gospel vocal quartet Oak Ridge Boys, has died at the age of 76.\n\nBonsall passed away on Tuesday due to complications with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Variety reported.\n\nIn January, Bonsall announced he would be retiring from touring with the quartet due to his battle with the disease.\n\nA tenor vocalist for the group, Bonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973 and in 2015 was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame alongside three of his bandmates.\n\nDuring his time with the musical group, the Oak Ridge Boys released their memorable hits Elvira, Bobbie Sue, and American Made.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a member of the country and gospel vocal quartet Oak Ridge Boys, has died at the age of 76; Bonsall pictured August 2022\n\nBoth Elvira and Bobbie Sue found success with country and pop fans - the 1981 track Elvira reached #1 on the country chart and 35 on Billboard's Hot 100 while Bobbie Sue, released in 1982, landed at 312 on the Hot 100 and was #1 on the country charts.\n\nAmerican Made, another crossover hit that peaked #1 on the Billboard Country Songs chart and 372 on the Hot 100, was released in 1983. It serves as the name of their current farewell tour, The Oak Ridge Boys American Made Farewell Tour.\n\nIn total, the group have had 15 songs reach #1 on the country charts. 34 of their songs have also reached top 10 in the country charts, according to Variety.\n\nIn a death notice furnished by his representatives, his team said, according to Variety: 'Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.'\n\nThe singer is survived by his wife Mary Ann, his two daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, great grandsons Chance and Grey, and sister Nancy, according to Variety.\n\nIn addition to his musical accomplishments, Bonsall was the author of 11 books. Bonsall's memoir, I See Myself, is also set for release this November.\n\nBonsall announced he would no longer be touring with the Oak Ridge Boys at the start of this year amid his battle with his disease.\n\n'Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,' he said in a statement obtained by People.\n\nIn January, Bonsall announced he would be retiring from touring with the quartet due to his battle with the disease; pictured August 2023\n\n'It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\n\n'I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.'\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys were founded in 1943 and skyrocketed to fame in the 1950s in Southern {"uri": "8217376473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:13:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:13:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:12:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.etonline.com/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-singer-dead-at-76-228755", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Oak Ridge Boys Singer, Dead at 76", "body": "The singer and author, best known for his 50-year run in the country and gospel vocal quartet The Oak Ridge Boys, died in Hendersonville, Tennessee, on Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), according to a press release.\n\nThe announcement stated that \"at the request of Joe, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\"\n\nBonsall was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall. He sang in different gospel music groups, including The Faith Four and The Keystone Quartet, in the state and later in New York until he moved to Tennessee in 1973 to join the Oaks, according to his website.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys have seen members come and go since its formation in 1943. Current members are Duane Allen, William Lee Golden, Richard Sterban and Ben James, who replaced Bonsall when he retired in January. Bonsall's tenor vocals and high harmonies can be heard on the group's many hit songs, including \"Elvira\" and \"Bobbie Sue.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys, who have sold more than 41 million records, won five GRAMMYs and were inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015. Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nBonsall's memoir, I See Myself, releases in November, marking his 11th book. Other books he authored include 2015's On the Road with The Oak Ridge Boys, a four-part children's book series titled The Molly Books, and a 2003 book about his parents titled GI Joe & Lillie.", {"uri": "2024-07-417528450", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:57:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:57:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/music/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-hall-of-famer/article_1bd85535-d0a6-53f0-bf21-38410cc1d839.html", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76 after half-century with Hall of Fame group", "body": "We've had to say goodbye to some beloved musicians, athletes, actors and more. Here's a look at the stars we've lost so far in 2024, through May.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Country Music Hall of Fame group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nAmong fellow music artists weighing in Bonsall's death was Blake Shelton, who posted this on social media: \"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've never seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and the Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nA tenor singer with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall announced in January that he was retiring from touring due to health issues. Ben James, formerly with Dailey & Vincent, replaced Bonsall in the touring lineup.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" Bonsall said in his retirement statement.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nPi Pizzeria closing last remaining location, in St. Louis' Central West End McClellan: Downtown St. Louis is a casualty of the do-gooder war Tropical Storm Beryl could hit St. Louis area with 4 inches of rain or more Hulk Hogan starts selling his new Real American Beer in Missouri, competing with Bud Light BenFred: Why Jordan Walker's name will provide hot-stove fodder as Cardinals near trade deadline Wentzville schools investigated board members for alleged retaliation, ethics violations Parades, fireworks and parties: Your guide to July 4th in St. Louis Several St. Louis-area cities move fireworks shows to Friday. Others cancel events. Messenger: She sold her house to help support her baby. Missouri's AG wants the money. Two dead in North County, 7 injured in downtown St. Louis during Fourth of July shootings Lars Nootbaar wondered about his spate of injuries, too. So he sought answers: Cardinals Extra July 4 chaos reignites safety concerns in downtown St. Louis. Chief blames 'small' group. Messenger: Judge fines St. Louis attorney for hiding documents on police shootings Extra! Extra! Read all about Cardinals' comeback from 5-run deficit to outlast Nats in 11th BenFred: Eli Drinkwitz's relentless recruiting has Mizzou beating brand names in away games\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn the same statement, Bonsall urged people to support his replacement (Ben James) in the Oak Ridge Boys, who have been managed for decades by Tulsa-based impresario Jim Halsey.\n\n\"God love you, Joe Bonsall,\" Halsey said. \"You have been an inspiration to fans, friends and family -- especially to me -- for 52 years. This is a very rough day.\"\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and, in addition to the Country Music Hall of Fame, is in the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nHe saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nOak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall retires from touring\n\nJimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\nOak Ridge Boys celebrating farewell tour, 51-year relationship with Jim Halsey\n\nJimmie Tramel Tulsa World\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall wrote 11 books. His memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November.\n\nSaid a news release from an Oak Ridge Boys publicist: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the promised day.\"\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWhat other members of the Oak Ridge Boys said:\n\nDuane Allen: \"When I look at Joe Bonsall's life, I see a life fulfilled. The son of two military veterans, he was raised to become street-smart in the hood-influenced neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. His parents taught him that he could be anything he wished to be if he worked hard, told the truth and trusted in God. Joe could do anything he set his mind to do, but what impressed me the most was the energy, love and compassion he put into everything he did and his unique gift to communicate those emotions and feelings into every performance, song and book. Joe was 'that' best friend that every person hopes to have in his life.\"\n\nWilliam Lee Golden: \"This has been a week of sadness with the loss of my son, Rusty Golden, and now the loss of our brother and our partner of over 50 years, Joe Bonsall. Thankfully we have the memories made and the songs that we've sang together to get us through. It gives me comfort to know that Joe and Rusty are together again. Our prayers are with his family.\"\n\nRichard Sterban: \"For many years, Joe was my best friend. We knew each other long before we both became members of The Oak Ridge Boys. He was a special person who was loved by everyone and was a true inspiration to us all. He was also the best singing partner a person could have. For several years he bravely fought a terrible disease and was a trooper right up until the very end. There is no doubt that today he is in a much better place -- at home with Jesus. I will see you soon my dear friend.\"\n\nBen James: \"Joe was a true hero to me. His singing is something that I have admired since I was a kid. Nobody could do it like Joe could do it. He was such an encouragement to me. I feel honored that he chose me to sing the tenor line when he decided to come off the road. I try my best for Joe and the Boys every night but only Joe can fill that spot. The legacy he leaves with us is something that is irreplaceable. I am forever thankful I got to know and love one of my all-time heroes that was nothing but good to me. I will miss Joe Bonsall. Thank you for loving everyone you met and making them feel like the most important person in your life when you spoke to them. A true gentleman.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on The country legend died from complications associated with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS.) Back in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring with the group due to his illness. Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November. At the request of Joe, there will be no funeral. {"uri": "8219255739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:07:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:07:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:03:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/blake-shelton-says-hes-heartbroken-185500713.html", "title": "Blake Shelton Says He's 'Heartbroken' over Joe Bonsall's Death: 'We All Lost a Special Person Today'", "body": "The Oak Ridge Boys' Bonsall died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) on July 9\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life,\" Shelton, 48, wrote alongside a photo performing with the band.\n\nHe continued, \"He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and his @theoakridgeboys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nIn 2016, Shelton collaborated with the Southern gospel group on his song \"Doing It to Country Songs.\"\n\nBonsall died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), according to a press release shared with PEOPLE.\n\nRelated: Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dies of ALS Complications at 76\n\nPer his request, a funeral will not be held for him but he encouraged donations be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nThe tenor singer announced his retirement from touring in January. At the time, he told PEOPLE he was prioritizing his health -- though he kept his exact diagnosis private.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe musician added, \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall -- who is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey and a sister, Nancy -- was a member of the Oak Ridge Boys for over 50 years before his death.\n\nRelated: The Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall Is Retiring from Touring Due to Neuromuscular Disorder: 'I Will Never Forget' (Exclusive)\n\nWith the group, which he joined in 1973, Bonsall landed in the prestigious Grand Ole Opry, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame. He was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame back in 1994.\n\nIn addition to his music, Bonsall was a published author. I will always be thankful to every person who came out to a show, bought a T-shirt, played our music, and overall, loved us enough to spend their hard-earned money whenever they could. {"uri": "8217499021", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:58:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:58:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:57:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies/article_c53f851f-d339-5d51-a63e-33d29f787cc0.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, celebrated tenor in the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nPeople are also reading... TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic 'Vampire' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Marion drive in entrance design sparks controversy, extra look by officials PREP FOOTBALL: Shane Wicks gets first head-coaching opportunity at Honaker White to fill board vacancy; Guffy selected new chair EO prepares for grand opening of new facility PREP FOOTBALL: Honaker hires Wicks LITTLE LEAGUE: State tournaments set across region and state Parades, music, fireworks on tap for Independence Day Dip Dog remains as popular as ever PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines PREP FOOTBALL: Chris Long says Heath Miller is right man for job at St. Anne's-Belfield Scientists say they've confirmed a slowdown in Earth's inner core rotation. Now what?\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug. He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a written statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nJohn Rich of country music duo Big & Rich shared a remembrance on X. Country music is crying today,\" he wrote. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness.\"\n\nCountry musician Travis Tritt also posted a tribute to Bonsall on X, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister Nancy; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; and great grandsons, Chance and Grey.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Bonsall was 76. According to a press release, cause of death was complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease.\n\nIn January, Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Oak Ridge Boys, announced he was retiring from touring due to the neuromuscular disorder. In a statement at that time, Bonsall said, \"I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. The Oak Ridge Boys will finish the Farewell Tour without me, but rest assured, I am good with all of it! God's Got It!!!\"\n\nSinger Ben James was brought in to sing Bonsall's parts, alongside longtime members Duane Allen, William Lee Golde, and Richard Sterban.\n\nOak Ridge Boys, a Grammy-winning gospel-tinged country vocal group with roots all the way back to the 1940s, have been inducted to Country Music Hall of Fame, Gospel Music Hall of Fame and Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nBonsall's memoir, \"I See Myself,\" is scheduled to publish in November. It will be his 11th book as an author. Outside of singing and the Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall's passions included playing banjo and watching Philadelphia Phillies baseball games.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nVia joint statement on social media, the surviving Oak Ridge Boys said, \"We ask that everyone please respect the privacy of the Bonsall family at this time.\"\n\nOn X/Twitter, country star Travis Tritt wrote, \"My heart is heavy this morning after hearing that my friend @oakridgeboys tenor @joebonsall has passed away at the age of 76. {"uri": "8217611464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:50:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:50:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:49:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/the-oak-ridge-boys-singer-joe-bonsall-dead-at-76-from-als/", "title": "Country Music Singer Joe Bonsall Dead at 76 From ALS Complications", "body": "Joe Bonsall, who was a longtime member of the country and gospel group The Oak Ridge Boys, died on Tuesday, July 9. He was 76.\n\nThe Grammy winner died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement released from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm and he loved the Philadelphia Phillies,\" read a statement on Bonsall's official website announcing his death. \"But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall served as a member of The Oak Ridge Boys for nearly 50 years and was inducted into the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nMonths before his death, Bonsall announced his retirement from The Oak Ridge Boys' ongoing Farewell Tour due to increasing health issues and immobility.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote via X in January. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. ... The @oakridgeboys will finish the Farewell Tour without me but rest assured I am good with all of it! God's Got It!!!\"\n\nIn addition to a successful music career, Bonsall was the author of 11 books including his upcoming memoir entitled I See Myself, which will be released in November.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, there will be no funeral service. In lieu of flowers, his family also asked for donations to be made to The ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nSoon after Bonsall's death was confirmed, many in the music industry shared their condolences and fond memories of the singer.\n\n\"We lost the great Joe Bonsall of the @oakridgeboys and country music is crying today,\" Jon Rich of Big and Rich fame wrote via X. \"Joe was a real friend, and someone I looked up to not only as an artist, but as a man. He's left a legacy of incredible music, and endless accounts of his kind heartedness. #RIPJoeBonsall.\"\n\nLee Greenwood added, \"Joe and I would have conversations on the road sometimes before a concert and sometimes afterwards about the crowd, the music and who we are as Americans. My family sends prayers to the Bonsall Family and The Oak Ridge Boys. {"uri": "8217318597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:28:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:28:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:28:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/joe-bonsall-50-member-oak-161619668.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, 50-Year-Member Of The Oak Ridge Boys, Has Died", "body": "Sad news out of Nashville today. Joe Bonsall, tenor singer for the legendary country group The Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). He was 76.\n\nBonsall announced his retirement from touring in January, revealing that life on the road had \"gotten too difficult,\" and that the neuromuscular disorder had robbed him of the ability to walk. He was replaced by Ben James.\n\nBorn in Philadelphia, Bonsall joined The Oak Ridge Boys in 1973. During his five-decade run with the group he was inducted into the Grand Ole Opry, the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame. The group famously performed \"Amazing Grace\" at president George H.W. Bush's funeral in Houston.\n\n\"Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November,\" his obituary reads. \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, {"uri": "2024-07-416676042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:29:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:29:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:10:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/07/09/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-cause-of-death-als-obituary/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, country-gospel star with the Oak Ridge Boys, dies from ALS at 76", "body": "Bonsall died from complications of ALS, which he battled for several years and forced him off the road in January, according to a statement from the group.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing,\" the statement read. \"He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973 and was part of the group during their massive commercial success of the 1980s, which included hits such as \"Elvira,\" \"Bonnie Sue\" and \"American Made.\"\n\nThe band became a touring mainstay for decades, with their crowd-pleasing combination of gospel, country and pop. Bonsall was on the road often during his five decades with the group, before stepping aside earlier this year as ALS impacted his life.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" he said in January. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nBorn May 18, 1948, in Philadelphia, Bonsall's music career took him to Harrisburg and Buffalo with different gospel groups before he moved to Hendersonville, Tenn., and joined the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\nThe group itself had been through turbulent times since it was founded in the 1940s, with multiple massive lineup changes and little commercial success to speak of. Even a cosign from Johnny Cash in 1973 and a record deal with Columbia couldn't propel them to success.\n\nBut in 1977, the Oak Ridge Boys released \"Y'all Come Back Saloon,\" and their run of country dominance began.\n\n\"In 1977 we knew we were on our way to making it when 'Y'all Come Back Saloon' was on every jukebox in the country,\" Bonsall told Ellicottville Now in 2023. \"You'd see four guys feeding the boxes quarters so they could play the song over and over again. It's a wonder we didn't get beat with a tire iron.\"\n\n\"Elvira,\" originally recorded in 1966 by Dallas Frazier, became the group's biggest hit in 1981, topping the country charts and reaching No. 5 on the Billboard Hot 100. The Oak Ridge Boys eventually racked up 17 No. 1 country hits through 1990.\n\nThey were inducted into the Gospel Music Hall of Fame in 2000, and the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015.\n\nAlong with his work as a singer, Bonsall also penned 10 books, including a four-part children's series. His 11th book, a memoir called \"I See Myself,\" is scheduled for release in November.\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing,\" country star Blake Shelton wrote Tuesday on social media. \"I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and his Oak Ridge Boys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; sister, Nancy, and two grandchildren.", "source": {"uri": "nydailynews.com", {"uri": "8217444626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:10:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:10:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:09:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://khak.com/ixp/204/p/oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-dead-tributes-stars-react/", "title": "JUST IN: Country Stars Mourn Oak Ridge Boys Singer Joe Bonsall", "body": "Longtime Oak Ridge Boys singer Joe Bonsall has died at the age of 76, and a number of his fellow country stars were among those who turned to social media to share their tributes to the late country legend.\n\nBonsall died on Tuesday (July 9) of complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), according to a statement from his publicist. The singer was a member of the Oak Ridge Boys for five decades before announcing his retirement from the group in January of 2024 due to his declining health.\n\nBonsall was a beloved figure in Nashville's music scene, and Blake Shelton was among those who reacted to the news of his death online, writing, \" I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life.\"\n\nTravis Tritt also weighed in, writing, \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him.\"\n\nBonsall sang lead on some of the Oak Ridge Boys' biggest hits, including \"Elvira,\" \"Bobbie Sue\" and \"American Made.\" He was a member of the Grand Ole Opry, the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame. In 2015, he was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame alongside the other Oak Ridge Boys.\n\nRelated: Country Stars Living With Serious Health Conditions\n\nThe Hall of Fame, the CMA and more country stars were among the others who paid tribute online. {"uri": "8217555459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:53:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:53:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:52:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.newsx.com/world/r-i-p-joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-legend-passes-away-at-76/", "title": "R.I.P Joe Bonsall: Oak Ridge Boys Legend Passes Away at 76", "body": "PM Modi Highlights Strong 25-Year Bond with Putin: 17 Meetings in 10 Years\n\nJoe Bonsall, known for his role as the tenor in The Oak Ridge Boys, passed away on Tuesday due to complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), according to an announcement by the group on their website and social media. He was 76 years old and passed away in Hendersonville, Tennessee. Earlier this year, Bonsall had announced his retirement from touring.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys, consisting of Bonsall along with Duane Allen, William Lee Golden, and Richard Sterban, initially gained fame as a gospel group. They transitioned to country music in 1977 with their hit \"Y'All Come Back Saloon,\" marking the beginning of a successful career that included 34 top 10 hits on Billboard's Top Country Songs chart.\n\nIn addition to Grammys, The Oak Ridge Boys received accolades from the Country Music Association (CMA) and the Academy of Country Music (ACM). They won CMA's Vocal Group of the Year in 1978 and Single of the Year in 1981 for \"Elvira,\" and secured four ACM Awards, including Top Vocal Group, Album of the Year for \"Ya'll Come Back Saloon\" in 1978, and Single Record of the Year for \"Elvira\" in 1981. Their enduring impact on music was further recognized with the Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award in 2007.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys achieved significant milestones in their career, including 17 chart-topping hits on Billboard's country chart, making them the third-highest among groups and duos, trailing only Alabama (33) and Brooks & Dunn (20). Their crossover success was notable with two songs, \"Elvira\" reaching No. 5 in 1981 and \"Bobbie Sue\" at No. 12 in 1982 on the Billboard Hot 100.\n\nREAD MORE: The Morning Show' Season 4: Jennifer Aniston Posts BTS Pic With Reese Witherspoon\n\nThey also secured three No. 1 albums on the Top Country Albums chart, with \"Fancy Free\" peaking at No. 14 in 1981 and \"Bobbie Sue\" at No. 20 in 1982 on the all-genre Billboard 200. Their musical prowess earned them five Grammy Awards, initially in gospel categories and later in country for \"Elvira,\" recognized as the best country performance by a duo or group.\n\nJoe Bonsall, a member of The Oak Ridge Boys for over 50 years, was honored with inductions into prestigious halls of fame, including the Grand Ole Opry, the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015. His contributions to music, spanning across genres and decades, solidified The Oak Ridge Boys' place as icons in American music history.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a statement. \"He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage. His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\n\"When I think of the Oak Ridge Boys and their place in country music history, the image of Joe with his huge smile and boundless energy comes to mind so clearly,\" Sarah Trahern, Country Music Association CEO, said in a statement. \"His commitment to serving others while developing country music into a worldwide sensation will never be forgotten and our industry has been made better because of him. Today, we lost an incomparable energy and voice in music. He will be missed greatly by all who were fortunate to know him.\"\n\nJoe Bonsall, in addition to his musical achievements, authored 11 books, including his upcoming memoir titled \"I See Myself,\" scheduled for release in November. Per Bonsall's wishes, there will be no funeral arrangements. Instead of flowers, contributions can be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; great-grandsons Chance and Grey; and his sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall. Bonsall's passing occurred just eight days following the death of William \"Rusty\" Golden, a musician, songwriter, and son of The Oak Ridge Boys' member William Lee Golden. Rusty Golden, aged 65, passed away on July 1 at his residence in Hendersonville.", "source": {"uri": "newsx.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsX"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217401849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:33:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:33:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:32:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/lifestyle/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-singer-dead-at-76/article_6661ec39-5d7d-505a-a651-7bd6bd03ed0d.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Oak Ridge Boys Singer, Dead at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, the tenor vocalist of music group The Oak Ridge Boys, passed away on July 9 after battling ALS for four years. He was 76 years old.\n\nThe news was reportedly shared by a spokesperson for the family, via Deadline. At the time of his death, Bonsall was living in Hendersonville, Tennessee.\n\nBonsall's death comes only days after Rusty Golden, the son of Oak Ridge Boys member William Lee Golden who was also a notable singer and musician, died. No cause of death was shared.\n\nThe band is known for hit songs like \"Elvira,\" \"Bobbie Sue,\" and \"I Guess It Never Hurts To Hurt Sometimes,\" among other major releases. The Oak Ridge Boys won five Grammys and were inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015.\n\nJust after passing his 50th anniversary of singing with the band, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring in January of this year at a concert.\n\nAccording to Deadline, Bonsall said of the decision, \"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" he added.\n\nA statement from Bonsall's reps after his death said: \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nThe singer is survived by his wife, Mary Bonsall, their daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, as well as two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.\n\nNext: Remembering the Stars and Legends We've Lost In 2024", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, {"uri": "2024-07-416578908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:13:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:13:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:09:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/music-news/joe-bonsall-dead-oak-ridge-boys-1235943725/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dies at 76", "body": "Shania Twain to Receive Music Icon Award and Perform at 2022 People's Choice Awards\n\nJoe Bonsall, the tenor in The Oak Ridge Boys, died on Tuesday from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), the group announced on its website and social media accounts.\n\nHe was 76, and died in Hendersonville, Tennessee. Bonsall had announced his retirement from touring at the beginning of the year.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys, in which Bonsall teamed with Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban, first found success as a gospel group. They segued into country music in 1977 with \"Y'All Come Back Saloon,\" their first of 34 top 10 hits on Billboard's Top Country Songs chart.\n\nThe Oaks landed 17 No. 1 hits on that chart, the third-highest total among duos and groups after Alabama (33) and Brooks & Dunn (20). Two of the Oaks' country chart-toppers became top 20 hits on the Billboard Hot 100 -- \"Elvira\" (No. 5 in 1981) and \"Bobbie Sue\" (No. 12 in 1982).\n\nThe group landed three No. 1 albums on Billboard's Top Country Albums chart, two of which became top 20 albums on the all-genre Billboard 200 -- Fancy Free (No. 14 in 1981) and Bobbie Sue (No. 20 in 1982).\n\nThe Oaks won five Grammys. The first four were in gospel categories; the fifth in country, for \"Elvira.\" That platinum-selling smash won best country performance by a duo or group with vocal.\n\nThe Oaks won two CMA awards -- vocal group of the year in 1978 and single of the year in 1981 for \"Elvira.\"\n\nThey won four ACM Awards -- top vocal group in 1978, album of the year that same year for Ya'll Come Back Saloon, single record of the year in 1981 for \"Elvira\" and the Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award in 2007. As a 50-year member of the The Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame, the latter in 2015.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a statement. \"He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage. His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\n\"When I think of the Oak Ridge Boys and their place in country music history, the image of Joe with his huge smile and boundless energy comes to mind so clearly,\" Sarah Trahern, Country Music Association CEO, said in a statement. \"His commitment to serving others while developing country music into a worldwide sensation will never be forgotten and our industry has been made better because of him. Today, we lost an incomparable energy and voice in music. He will be missed greatly by all who were fortunate to know him.\"\n\nBonsall was also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which is set for release in November.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center. Survivors include his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; two great grandsons, Chance and Grey; and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nBonsall's death comes just eight days after the death of William \"Rusty\" Golden, a musician, songwriter and son of The Oak Ridge Boys member William Lee Golden. The younger Golden died on July 1 at his home in Hendersonville, Tenn. {"uri": "8217397539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:29:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:29:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:29:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/joe-bonsall-dead-oak-ridge-boys-member-obituary-1235727226/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dies at 76", "body": "Artifacts From BTS, SEVENTEEN & More HYBE Artists to Be Displayed in Grammy Museum Exhibit\n\nJoe Bonsall, the tenor in The Oak Ridge Boys, died on Tuesday (July 9) from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), the group announced on its website and social media accounts. He was 76, and died in Hendersonville, Tenn. Bonsall had announced his retirement from touring at the beginning of the year.\n\nIn 1973, Bonsall left his position with gospel group The Keystones to join The Oak Ridge Boys. The Oaks, in which Bonsall teamed with Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban, first found success as a gospel group. They segued into country music in 1977 with \"Y'All Come Back Saloon,\" their first of 34 top 10 hits on Billboard's Top Country Songs chart.\n\nThe Oaks landed 17 No. 1 hits on that chart, the third-highest total among duos and groups after Alabama (33) and Brooks & Dunn (20). Two of the Oaks' country chart-toppers became top 20 hits on the Billboard Hot 100 - \"Elvira\" (No. 5 in 1981) and \"Bobbie Sue\" (No. 12 in 1982).\n\nThe group landed three No. 1 albums on Billboard's Top Country Albums chart, two of which became top 20 albums on the all-genre Billboard 200 - Fancy Free (No. 14 in 1981) and Bobbie Sue (No. 20 in 1982).\n\nThe Oaks won five Grammys. The first four were in gospel categories; the fifth in country, for \"Elvira.\" That platinum-selling smash won best country performance by a duo or group with vocal.\n\nThe Oaks won two CMA awards - vocal group of the year in 1978 and single of the year in 1981 for \"Elvira.\"\n\nThey won four ACM Awards - top vocal group in 1978, album of the year that same year for Ya'll Come Back Saloon, single record of the year in 1981 for \"Elvira\" and the Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award in 2007.\n\nAs a 50-year member of the The Oak Ridge Boys, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame, the latter in 2015.\n\n\"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a statement. \"He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage. His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\n\"When I think of the Oak Ridge Boys and their place in country music history, the image of Joe with his huge smile and boundless energy comes to mind so clearly,\" Sarah Trahern, Country Music Association CEO, said in a statement. \"His commitment to serving others while developing country music into a worldwide sensation will never be forgotten and our industry has been made better because of him. Today, we lost an incomparable energy and voice in music. He will be missed greatly by all who were fortunate to know him.\"\n\nBonsall was also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which is set for release in November.\n\nBonsall's final show with the Oaks was on Dec. 17, 2023. In January, he revealed that he had battled the slow onset of a neuromuscular disorder for more than four years. \"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" he said in a statement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; two great grandsons, Chance and Grey; and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nBonsall's death comes just eight days after the death of William \"Rusty\" Golden, a musician, songwriter and son of The Oak Ridge Boys member William Lee Golden. The younger Golden died on July 1 at his home in Hendersonville, Tenn. He was 65. William Lee Golden said in a statement at that time, \"This is the hardest thing ever for a father to have to face. I love family more than anything. Rusty was a great musician, a talented songwriter and a wonderful son. We appreciate your thoughts and prayers for the days ahead. I love you, son.\"", "source": {"uri": "billboard.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Billboard"}, "authors": [{"uri": "paul_grein@billboard.com", "name": "Paul Grein", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elvira_(song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Elvira (song)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Bonsall", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Bonsall"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Oak_Ridge_Boys", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "The Oak Ridge Boys"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gospel_music", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Gospel music"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Record_chart", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Record chart"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobbie_Sue_(song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Bobbie Sue (song)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tenor", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Tenor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billboard_(magazine)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Billboard (magazine)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country_music", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Country music"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top_Country_Albums", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Top Country Albums"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BTS", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "BTS"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duane_Allen", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Duane Allen"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Sterban", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Richard Sterban"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Museum_at_L.A._Live", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Grammy Museum at L.A. {"uri": "8217758954", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:37:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:37:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:37:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.wsmv.com/2024/07/09/oak-ridge-boys-bonsall-leaves-behind-musical-legacy-dies-76/", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Bonsall leaves behind musical legacy, dies at 76", "body": "HENDERSONVILLE, Tenn. (WSMV) - Born in Philadelphia in the late 1940s, Joe Bonsall always had a love for music.\n\nHis personal affection for gospel and his ability to sing garnered him a spot in his first group, the Keystones. In 1973, he'd leave the Philly-based Gospel group to join the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\n\"Right after he joined is when they really became nationally known and became country music stars,\" Michael McCall said.\n\nBonsall's unmistakable tenor voice joined a powerhouse musical group and remained there for the rest of his life.\n\nBonsall saw the group through its golden years, with chart-topping singles like 'Elvira' in 1981, 'Bobbie Sue' in 1982, and 'American Made' in 1983.\n\n\"It was a real presentation going on there with a lot of energy, and like I said, I think Joe was the most energetic,\" McCall said.\n\nDuring his five decades with the group, Bonsall was a well-known member of the Grand Ole Opry. The group was inducted into the Gospel Hall of Fame in 2000, and just 15 years later, etched their names in history at the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"It's an incredible thing for us,\" Bonsall said at the time. \"It represents a lot of songs and a lot of miles and a lot of stuff together, and to have this happen to us, man it's gigantic, it's huge.\"\n\nBonsall's health declined in the years to follow. His known battle with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) started in 2020.\n\n\"He was a very active man, and he always said I'm going to stay active, I'm going to stay active,\" McCall said of Bonsall.\n\nThe longtime singer did just that for as long as he could, up until the group's Farewell Tour this past year.\n\nIn January, the singer shared he could no longer walk and was retiring from the tour.\n\nThe band shared the following obituary on their website on Tuesday:\n\n\"Joseph S. Bonsall (76) of Hendersonville, Tennessee passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAs a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nJoseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November. Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.", "source": {"uri": "wsmv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WSMV Nashville"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8217443549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:09:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:09:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:08:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.masslive.com/entertainment/2024/07/longtime-member-of-legendary-country-music-group-dies-at-76.html", "title": "Longtime member of legendary country music group dies at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, the tenor of The Oak Ridge Boys who helped the country music group achieve crossover success, died in Hendersonville, Tennessee on Tuesday, July 9 from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), the group said on Intsagram. He was 76.\n\nAs a 50-year member of the group, Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame, according to the Instagram post.\n\nOutside of music, Bonsall was the author of 11 books including his memoir \"I See Myself,\" which is scheduled for release in November. Bonsall announced his retirement from touring at the beginning of the year.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies,\" the Instagram post reads. \"But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nThe singer leaves behind his wife Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and his sister Nancy.\n\nPer his request there will be no funeral for Bonsall, but donations to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center are encouraged.\n\n\"For fifty years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame said on X. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nBonsall, who joined The Oaks in the early 1970s, was part of the group's lineup that produced their best-known country and crossover hits including \"Elvira,\" \"Bobbie Sue,\" and \"American Made.\"\n\nThe lineup at the time also consisted of lead vocalist Duane Allen, baritone William Lee Golden and bass singer Richard Sterban.\n\nAfter making the jump from gospel music to country, The Oak Ridge Boys landed a hit in 1977 with \"Y'All Come Back Saloon,\" their first of 34 top 10 hits on Billboard's Top Country Songs chart.\n\nThe Oaks landed 17 No. 1 hits on that chart, the third-highest total among duos and groups after Alabama (33) and Brooks & Dunn (20), according to Billboard.\n\nThe group also landed three No. 1 albums on Billboard's Top Country Albums chart, two of which became top 20 albums on the all-genre Billboard 200 -- \"Fancy Free\" (No. 14 in 1981) and \"Bobbie Sue\" (No. 20 in 1982), the outlet reported.\n\nThe Oaks have {"uri": "2024-07-416512950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:57:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:57:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:27:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/music/2024/07/09/joe-bonsall-death-oak-ridge-boys-als/74338544007/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Oak Ridge Boys singer, dies at 76 from ALS complications", "body": "Bonsall's and the group's representatives on Tuesday confirmed his death.\n\nNotably, alongside his Country Music Hall of Fame and Grand Ole Opry membership, Bonsall was an inductee of the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame and Gospel Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer,\" stated Bonsall in January to The Nashville Tennessean, part of the USA TODAY Network.\n\nThe Philadelphia native had already been replaced on the road by bluegrass and gospel performer Ben James alongside Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban. In November 2022, James appeared with the quartet who, while performing on the same billing as Dailey & Vincent, brought him onstage to perform their 40-year-old crossover smash \"Elvira.\"\n\n\"Joe handed me the mic and said, 'You've got the next verse. And I'm not sure I will ever get over that moment. 'Elvira' was always on repeat when I was growing up. It's still one of those timeless songs that never grow old,\" offered James in a press statement.\n\nJoe Bonsall health issues with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis caused retirement\n\nBonsall retired from performing on the road with the group after 50 years six months ago, citing the half-decade onset of his ALS diagnosis.\n\nIn a December feature, Bonsall described a career as an Oak Ridge Boy member that saw him play over 10,000 concerts in amphitheaters, arenas, stadiums and theaters worldwide as bearing witness to an \"amazing phenomenon\" that \"took on a life of its own\" and \"marks so many unique spaces, stories and times.\"\n\nHe added that the group \"represented the place to be for five decades. Four guys who looked like they shouldn't even know each other have blended harmonies and had a celebrated career.\"\n\nHow Joe Bonsall embraced being one of The Oak Ridge Boys members\n\nBonsall became an Oak Ridge Boy in October 1973, the 30th of 35 total performers to perform in the group since its 1947 inception.\n\nFor 35 years, The Oak Ridge Boys achieved excellence as a Southern gospel quartet with soulful leanings. However, by the mid-1970s, the group evolved its image in a cosmopolitan direction. Clad in suits from Hollywood fashion designer Harvey Krantz, they began emphasizing \"entertainment\" over preaching to create a mainstream pop-ready, GQ-style country act.\n\nThat spurred a run of 14 Top 10 Billboard Country chart singles, began with 1977's \"Y'all Come Back Saloon\" and included songs like \"Elvira\" and \"American Made\" among many hits.\n\nThat success was marked by moments like 1978's NBC-broadcasted \"World's Largest Indoor Country Music Show,\" where the Oak Ridge Boys appeared at Detroit's Pontiac Silverdome alongside Kenny Rogers, Minnie Pearl, Dottie West and numerous others.\n\n\"We're out there in front of a national audience and 60,000 people running all over the stage singing country music and then we put that big gospel ending on it. It was a feeling like nothing else I'd felt to that point,\" Bonsall recalled to The Tennessean.\n\nJoe Bonsall's other notable career interests\n\nOver the past three decades, the vocalist was also the author of 11 books, including \"The Molly Books,\" a four-part children's book series, 2003's \"GI Joe and Lillie,\" about his parents' lives during and after World War II, plus his forthcoming memoir, \"I See Myself,\" which is still scheduled for a Nov. 13, 2024 release.\n\nAbout his memoir, a press statement notes the following:\n\n\"In 'I See Myself,' Joe Bonsall reflects on his life's contrasts and crossroads. From growing up in the inner city of Philadelphia to sitting on the front porch of his log home in rural Tennessee. From hanging with a street gang in his teens to surrendering to Christ at a youth camp. From working as a short order cook to headlining sold-out arenas. And now -- from running across the stage each night to being sidelined by a neuromuscular disorder that has stolen his mobility. However, despite the changing circumstances of Joe's life, two things have not changed. His unwavering faith in God. And his ability to inspire others.\"\n\nBonsall's memoir is currently available for pre-order via Amazon.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8217281204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:02:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:02:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:02:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://975kgkl.com/ixp/204/p/oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-dead-dies/", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys Singer Joe Bonsall Dead at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, a tenor singer and longtime member of the Oak Ridge Boys, died on Tuesday (July 9) of complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS.) He was 76 years old.\n\nHis death was announced in a statement from the band's publicity team. Bonsall announced his retirement from touring back in January due to the progression of his illness.\n\nBorn on May 18, 1948, in Philadelphia, Penn., Bonsall spent five decades as an Oak Ridge Boys member, singing on hits such as \"Elvira,\" \"Bobbie Sue\" and \"American Made.\" As part of his work with the group, he was a member of the Grand Ole Opry, the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame. In 2015, he and his bandmates were inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nIn addition to his work in music, Bonsall was the author of 11 books, including a memoir called I See Myself that is slated for release in November.\n\nBeginning last September, Bonsall toured with the Oaks for their American Made: Farewell Tour. However, in January, he announced his decision to retire, explaining that his neuromuscular disorder had made walking impossible. He was replaced by a 27-year-old singer named Ben James.\n\nBonsall was open about his health struggles in his latter years. He had a brush with death in 2022 after doctors found pulmonary embolisms, requiring a six-day hospital stay. \"I could have easily died last weekend but God is not through with me yet,\" he told fans in a tweet following that experience.\n\nRelated: Country Stars Living With Serious Health Conditions\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys have been affected by multiple tragedies this year. Bonsall's death comes just one week after singer William Lee Golden announced the death of his son, William \"Rusty\" Golden, who died at age 65 at his Nashville-area home.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina and multiple grandchildren and great-grandchildren. His family is requesting privacy as they grieve his loss.\n\nAt the singer's request, there will be no funeral service. Announces New Chief Financial Officer", "body": "OAK RIDGE, N.C., July 08, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Oak Ridge Financial Services, Inc. (\"Oak Ridge\"; the \"Company\") (OTCPink: BKOR), the parent company of Bank of Oak Ridge (the \"Bank\"), officially announces the promotion of Kevin Reid to Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President.\n\n\"I am delighted to share that Kevin Reid has been promoted to Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President of Bank of Oak Ridge and Oak Ridge Financial Services, Inc.,\" said Thomas W. Wayne, CEO. \"With an extensive background in accounting and auditing in the financial services industry, Kevin has played a unique and pivotal role in enhancing the Bank's financial health and strengthening our risk position.\"\n\nReid joined Bank of Oak Ridge in May 2021 and served as Controller and Vice President prior to his promotion. He is a North Carolina Certified Public Accountant with a Bachelor of Business Administration Degree in Accounting from Radford University. He has more than a decade of experience in public accounting and auditing. Reid serves as the Bank's Information Security Officer and will maintain this role in conjunction with his promotion to CFO. He also serves as one of four trustees for Bank of Oak Ridge's Employee Stock Ownership Plan.\n\n\"Kevin has demonstrated exemplary leadership of the Accounting and Information Technology Departments. He has made notable contributions to both areas with respect to risk mitigation, regulatory and financial reporting, and information and cybersecurity controls,\" said Thomas W. Wayne, CEO. \"He is distinctly qualified to serve the Bank as CFO, and we are excited for the diverse skillset and experience he will bring to the role.\"\n\nWayne has served as the Bank's CFO since the Bank founding in 2000 until present, along with serving as President since 2016 and CEO since 2019. Following Reid's promotion, Wayne will continue to lead the Bank in his present role as CEO and as a member of the Bank and Company's Board of Directors.\n\n\"As our Bank continues to grow, it is time for my role to evolve. I am honored to pass the CFO baton to Kevin, allowing me to fully focus on my role as Chief Executive Officer,\" said Thomas W. Wayne, CEO.\n\nAbout Oak Ridge Financial Services, Inc.\n\nBank of Oak Ridge is an employee-owned community bank that delivers Spectacularly Local banking. {"uri": "8217294144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:15:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:15:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:10:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-160748063.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Oak Ridge Boys tenor vocalist, dies at 76 from ALS complications", "body": "Joe Bonsall, 76, the longtime tenor vocalist of Country Music Hall of Fame inducted and Grand Ole Opry cast member quintet the Oak Ridge Boys, has died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The announcement was made on July 9 by representatives of the artist and the group.\n\nSix months ago, citing the half-decade onset of the previously-mentioned disorder, Bonsall retired from performing on the road with the group after 50 years.\n\nNotably, alongside his Country Music Hall of Fame and Grand Ole Opry membership, Bonsall was an inductee of the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame and Gospel Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer,\" stated Bonsall in January to The Tennessean.\n\nThe Philadelphia native had already been replaced on the road by bluegrass and gospel performer Ben James alongside Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban. In November 2022, James appeared with the quartet who, while performing on the same billing as Dailey & Vincent, brought him onstage to perform their 40-year-old crossover smash \"Elvira.\"\n\n\"Joe handed me the mic and said, 'You've got the next verse. And I'm not sure I will ever get over that moment. 'Elvira' was always on repeat when I was growing up. It's still one of those timeless songs that never grow old,\" offered James in a press statement.\n\nIn a Dec. 2023 feature, Bonsall described a career as an Oak Ridge Boy member that saw him play over 10,000 concerts in amphitheaters, arenas, stadiums and theaters worldwide as bearing witness to an \"amazing phenomenon\" that \"took on a life of its own\" and \"marks so many unique spaces, stories and times.\"\n\nHe added that the group \"represented the place to be for five decades. Four guys who looked like they shouldn't even know each other have blended harmonies and had a celebrated career.\"\n\nBonsall became an Oak Ridge Boy in Oct. 1973, the 30th of 35 total performers to perform in the group since its 1947 inception.\n\nFor 35 years, The Oak Ridge Boys achieved excellence as a Southern gospel quartet with soulful leanings. However, by the mid-1970s, the group evolved its image in a cosmopolitan direction. Clad in suits from Hollywood fashion designer Harvey Krantz, they began emphasizing \"entertainment\" over preaching to create a mainstream pop-ready, GQ-style country act.\n\nThat spurred a run of 14 Top 10 Billboard Country chart singles, began with 1977's \"Y'all Come Back Saloon\" and included songs like \"Elvira\" and \"American Made\" among many hits.\n\nThat success was marked by moments like 1978's NBC-broadcasted \"World's Largest Indoor Country Music Show,\" where the Oak Ridge Boys appeared at Detroit's Pontiac Silverdome alongside Kenny Rogers, Minnie Pearl, Dottie West and numerous others.\n\n\"We're out there in front of a national audience and 60,000 people running all over the stage singing country music and then we put that big gospel ending on it. It was a feeling like nothing else I'd felt to that point,\" Bonsall recalled to The Tennessean.\n\nOver the past three decades, the vocalist was also the author of 11 books, including \"The Molly Books,\" a four-part children's book series, 2003's \"GI Joe and Lillie,\" about his parents' lives during and after World War II, plus his forthcoming memoir, \"I See Myself,\" which is still scheduled for a Nov. 13, 2024 release.\n\nAbout his memoir, a press statement notes the following:\n\n\"In 'I See Myself,' Joe Bonsall reflects on his life's contrasts and crossroads. From growing up in the inner city of Philadelphia to sitting on the front porch of his log home in rural Tennessee. From hanging with a street gang in his teens to surrendering to Christ at a youth camp. From working as a short order cook to headlining sold-out arenas. And now -- from running across the stage each night to being sidelined by a neuromuscular disorder that has stolen his mobility. However, despite the changing circumstances of Joe's life, two things have not changed. His unwavering faith in God. And his ability to inspire others.\"\n\nBonsall's memoir is currently available for pre-order via Amazon.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8217252644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:43:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:43:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:43:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2024/07/09/joe-bonsall-longtime-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member Of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dead At 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, who served as a member of the Oak Ridge Boys since 1973 before announcing that he was stepping away from touring earlier this year, passed away today at the age of 76 due to complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, or ALS - also known as Lou Gehrig's disease.\n\nThe group that would become the Oak Ridge Boys has been around since 1941, when the quartet out of Oak Ridge, Tennessee got their start as Wally Fowler and the Georgia Clodhoppers. But because they were often asked to sing for service members and their families at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, the group changed their name to the Oak Ridge Quartet before becoming the Oak Ridge Boys in 1961.\n\nThe current lineup of the Oaks was completed in 1973, and for the last 50 years has featured lead singer Duane Allen, tenor Joe Bonsall, baritone William Lee Golden (and his iconic beard), and bass Richard Sterban.\n\nOver the past 50 years The Oak Ridge Boys have become icons of country music with hits like \"American Made,\" \"Bobbie Sue,\" \"Leaving Louisiana In The Broad Daylight,\" \"Fancy Free,\" and of course their biggest hit, \"Elvira.\" And they've also become well known for the mark they've left on the gospel world, having even performed \"Amazing Grace\" at the funeral of President George H.W. Bush back in 2018.\n\nBut Bonsall announced back in January that he would be stepping away from touring due to a neuromuscular disorder that has left him unable to walk.\n\nBonsall said at the time:\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\n\nIt has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\n\nThere is a young man named Ben James singing for me out there, and he needs your love and encouragement ... his sound is different than mine, but he brings a ton of talent to the table!\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys will finish the Farewell Tour without me, but rest assured, I am good with all of it! God's Got It!!!\"\n\nIn many ways the face of the group, Bonsall was well known for interacting with fans on Twitter and showing off his beloved cat, Barney. And one of the coolest moments of my career came last year when I had the opportunity to sit down and talk to the legendary Oak Ridge Boys, including Bonsall. It was like sitting down with royalty - and they were just as nice in person as you would expect them to be.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S.
