{"uri": "8217264773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:51:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:51:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:51:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://deadline.com/2024/07/joe-bonsall-dead-1236004518/", "title": "Joe Bonsall Dies: Longtime Oak Ridge Boys Singer Was 76", "body": "Hot Dog! Patrick Bertoletti Is New Champ At Coney Island Eating Contest, Succeeding The Vegan-Endorsing & Banned Joey Chestnut\n\nJoe Bonsall, the longtime member with the Oak Ridge Boys who retired in January following a four-year battle with the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, died today, July 9. He was 76.\n\nHis death was announced by a spokesperson for the Bonsall family.\n\nThe news comes less that ten days after the July 1 death of Rusty Golden, the 65-year-old musician son of The Oak Ridge Boys' William Lee Golden. Both Golden and Bonsall were residents of Hendersonville, Tennessee.\n\nBonsall joined the popular country and gospel singing group the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973, and his tenor vocals and high harmonies quickly became an integral part of the group's sound on on such hits as \"Elvira\" and \"Bobbie Sue.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys, which has sold more than 41 million records, won five Grammys and was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015. The group was founded in 1943 as the Oak Ridge Quartet, changing its name to the Oak Ridge Boys in the 1960s as it moved from its original bluegrass sound to gospel and eventually country.\n\nBonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nBonsall's memoir I See Myself will be released in November. The book will be Bonsall's 11th, with others including a four-part children's book series titled The Molly Books and a 2003 book about his parents titled GI Joe and Lillie.\n\nThe Bonsall family's announcement today read, in part, \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBorn May 18, 1948, Bonsall said at the time of his retirement in January, \"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall also offered kind words for his replacement in the group: \"There is a young man named Ben James singing for me out there, and he needs your love and encouragement.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by wife Mary Ann; daughters Jennifer and Sabrina; granddaughter Breanne; grandson Luke; greatgrandsons Chance and Grey; and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt Bonsall's request, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "deadline.com", "dataType": "news", The degenerative nervous system disease can affect nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.\n\nBonsall announced on social media about six months ago that he was leaving the group.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nBonsall noted that \"it has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\n\"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying,\" he added.\n\nBonsall explained at the time that Ben James is singing in the group in his stead, writing that \"his sound is different than mine but he brings a ton of talent to the table!\"\n\n\"The @oakridgeboys will finish the Farewell Tour without me but rest assured I am good with all of it!\" he concluded. \"God's Got It!!!\"\n\nThe country and gospel quartet, originally founded in 1943 out ot Tennessee, are known for songs including \"Elvira\" and \"American Made.\" Bonsall joined the group in 1973.\n\nDuring his long career, Bonsall became a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nHe was also the author of 11 books, including a memoir titled, \"I See Myself: Musings and Memories of a Blessed Life,\" which is set to be published in November.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the announcement from his management reads. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance, and Grey, and a sister, Nancy.\n\nAt his request, there will be no funeral and in lieu of flowers donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8219290320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:36:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:36:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:36:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.dailywire.com/news/famed-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76", "title": "Famed Member Of The Oak Ridge Boys Dead At 76", "body": "Famed member of the country group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe Bonsall, has died at the age of 76 -- after announcing in January that he was leaving the group due to a neuromuscular disorder.\n\nIn a heartbreaking post on Tuesday on X from the hugely successful country and gospel group, the band announced that their longtime member had died from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). The degenerative nervous system disease can affect nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, CNN noted.\n\n\"As a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, The Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame,\" the post read.\n\n\"Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir titled 'I See Myself,' which releases in November,\" the post added. \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nNo funeral is planned and in lieu of \"flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center,\" the post continued. \"The family is requesting privacy.\"\n\nKyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a statement, \"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" Billboard reported.\n\n\"He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Young added. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nIn January, Bonsall shared the news he was leaving the group and would not be part of the rest of its Farewell Tour that kicked off in 2023, due to his health issues.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\n\"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying,\" he added. \"The @oakridgeboys will finish the Farewell Tour without me but rest assured I am good with all of it! God's Got It!!!\"\n\nThe country group was originally founded in 1943 in Tennessee, with Bonsall joining in 1973. The band is probably best known for such hits as \"Elvira\" and \"American Made,\" CNN noted.\n\nHe is survived by his wife Mary Ann, two daughters, a granddaughter, a grandson, two great grandsons, {"uri": "8217459255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:21:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:21:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:20:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.abcactionnews.com/news/national-news/joe-bonsall-a-50-year-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76", "title": "Joe Bonsall, a 50-year member of The Oak Ridge Boys, dead at 76", "body": "NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- Joe Bonsall, who left the legendary singing group The Oak Ridge Boys after 50 years in January due to a neuromuscular disorder, has died, his management team announced Tuesday.\n\nHe was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), according to his representatives. The degenerative nervous system disease can affect nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.\n\nBonsall announced on social media about six months ago that he was leaving the group.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\nBonsall noted that \"it has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\n\"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying,\" he added.\n\nBonsall explained at the time that Ben James is singing in the group in his stead, writing that \"his sound is different than mine but he brings a ton of talent to the table!\"\n\n\"The @oakridgeboys will finish the Farewell Tour without me but rest assured I am good with all of it!\" he concluded. \"God's Got It!!!\"\n\nThe country and gospel quartet, originally founded in 1943 out ot Tennessee, are known for songs including \"Elvira\" and \"American Made.\" Bonsall joined the group in 1973.\n\nDuring his long career, Bonsall became a member of the Grand Ole Opry and was inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nHe was also the author of 11 books, including a memoir titled, \"I See Myself: Musings and Memories of a Blessed Life,\" which is set to be published in November.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the announcement from his management reads. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance, and Grey, and a sister, Nancy.\n\nAt his request, there will be no funeral and in lieu of flowers donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nWoman captures video of bear in Polk County roaming around a neighborhood\n\nWoman captures video of bear in Lakeland roaming around a neighborhood\n\nAnonymous messaging app allegedly sent 'fake' messages, exposed kids to bullying\n\nScripps News Staff\n\n2:07 PM, Jul 09, 2024\n\nGypsy Rose Blanchard expecting first child with boyfriend Ken Urker\n\nElina Tarkazikis\n\n1:52 PM, Jul 09, 2024\n\nFormer Sen. {"uri": "8219253007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:02:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:02:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:00:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://people.com/blake-shelton-heartbroken-over-oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-death-8675997", "title": "Blake Shelton Says He's 'Heartbroken' over Joe Bonsall's Death: 'We All Lost a Special Person Today'", "body": "After the tragic news of his death on Tuesday, July 9, the \"Sangria\" singer remembered the late Oak Ridge Boys member with a tribute post on X.\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsall's passing. I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life,\" Shelton, 48, wrote alongside a photo performing with the band.\n\nHe continued, \"He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and his @theoakridgeboys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nIn 2016, Shelton collaborated with the Southern gospel group on his song \"Doing It to Country Songs.\"\n\nBonsall died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), according to a press release shared with PEOPLE.\n\nPer his request, a funeral will not be held for him but he encouraged donations be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nThe tenor singer announced his retirement from touring in January. At the time, he told PEOPLE he was prioritizing his health -- though he kept his exact diagnosis private.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe musician added, \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nBonsall -- who is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey and a sister, Nancy -- was a member of the Oak Ridge Boys for over 50 years before his death.\n\nWith the group, which he joined in 1973, Bonsall landed in the prestigious Grand Ole Opry, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame. He was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame back in 1994.\n\nIn addition to his music, Bonsall was a published author. He wrote 11 books, including a memoir titled I See Myself, which will be released in November.\n\nIn September the band announced a celebratory farewell tour to commemorate their 50th anniversary.\n\n\"We are doing a farewell tour because we owe it to our fans to say goodbye,\" William Lee Golden said in a press release. \"They have always been there for us through the good times and the bad. I will always be thankful to every person who came out to a show, bought a T-shirt, played our music, and overall, loved us enough to spend their hard-earned money whenever they could. His commitment to serving others while developing Country Music into a worldwide sensation will never be forgotten and our industry has been made better because of him. Today, we lost an incomparable energy and voice in music. He will be missed greatly by all who were fortunate to know him,\" Country Music Association CEO Sarah Trahern said.\n\nHere's what you need to know about Joe Bonsall's death and The Oak Ridge Boys:\n\nJOE BONSALL, LONG TIME MEMBER OF THE OAK RIDGE BOYS, DEAD AT 76\n\nMay 18, 1948 - July 9, 2024\n\nHENDERSONVILLE, Tenn. - Joseph S. Bonsall (76) of Hendersonville, Tennessee passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAs a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nJoseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November. Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\n\nAt the request of Joe, there will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association\n\nVanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center\n\nThe family is requesting privacy.\n\njosephsbonsall.com", {"uri": "8217478081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:39:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:39:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:38:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://abc7amarillo.com/news/entertainment/oak-ridge-boys-joseph-bonsall-dies-at-76-leaves-behind-enduring-music-legacy-elvira-country-hall-of-fame-accolades-gospel-author", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall dies at 76, leaves behind enduring music legacy", "body": "HENDERSONVILLE, Tenn. -- Joe Bonsall, the cherished voice of The Oak Ridge Boys, passed away on Tuesday, succumbing to complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis at the age of 76.\n\nHe leaves behind a legacy that resonates far beyond the realms of music.\n\nA stalwart member of The Oak Ridge Boys for five decades, Joe Bonsall was not just a singer but a cultural icon, gracing the stages of the Grand Ole Opry and receiving accolades from the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the esteemed Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nJoe Bonsall's contribution to The Oak Ridge Boys stands as a testament to both his vocal prowess and his unwavering dedication to the group's evolution.\n\nJoining in 1973, Bonsall brought a distinctive tenor to the quartet, enriching their sound with his versatile range and charismatic stage presence. His arrival marked a pivotal moment in the band's trajectory, coinciding with their transition from gospel roots to mainstream success. As a key songwriter and arranger, Bonsall played a crucial role in shaping their signature hits, infusing their music with heartfelt emotion and infectious energy that resonated with audiences worldwide.\n\nEmerging in the early 1960s as a gospel quartet, the group underwent several transformations before solidifying their lineup in the 1970s with Bonsall, Duane Allen, William Lee Golden, and Richard Sterban. Their signature four-part harmonies became synonymous with hits like \"Elvira,\" which topped the charts and earned them crossover success.\n\nBeyond his musical achievements, Joseph was a prolific author, penning 11 books, including his upcoming memoir, \"I See Myself,\" set for release in November. His passions were as diverse as his talents: from banjo picking to farming, and his unwavering devotion to the Philadelphia Phillies.\n\nHe is survived by his beloved wife Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and sister Nancy.\n\nIn accordance with his wishes, there will be no funeral service. Instead, donations in Joe's memory can be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "abc7amarillo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-07-417335728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:13:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:13:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:52:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.comingsoon.net/guides/news/1796533-what-happened-to-joe-bonsall-death-als-disease", "title": "What Happened to Joe Bonsall? Oak Ridge Boys Member Passes Away", "body": "Country music fans are mourning the death of Joe Bonsall, a beloved member of the iconic Oak Ridge Boys. Bonsall was a powerful vocalist and a captivating performer who played a pivotal role in the group's long-lasting success, and his passing raises questions about the future of the Oak Ridge Boys and the impact it will have on their enduring legacy.\n\nSo, what happened to Joe Bonsall? Discover details about Joe Bonsall's cause of death and his legacy here.\n\nJoe Bonsall passes away at 76, claims report\n\nJoe Bonsall, the longtime tenor in the Oak Ridge Boys, passed away at 76 on July 9, 2024, due to complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), the group announced.\n\nAccording to Variety, Bonsall retired from touring earlier this year due to Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS disease), which was Joe Bonsall's cause of death. This brought an end to his more than five-decade-long career with the legendary country and gospel group.\n\nBorn in Philadelphia, Bonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973, quickly becoming a vital member of the group. The group transitioned from gospel to country music in the late 1970s, achieving major success with hits like \"Elvira\" and \"Bobbie Sue,\" earning them multiple awards, including five Grammys.\n\nBonsall's impact went beyond music. He authored 11 books, including the recent memoir I See Myself, showcasing his diverse talents. His vibrant stage presence endeared him to fans and colleagues, who have celebrated his lasting legacy in the music industry.\n\nAs per CNN, his family has requested that, instead of flowers, donations be made to the ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nBonsall's passing marks the end of an era for the Oak Ridge Boys. His influence and contributions to both gospel and country music will be remembered and cherished. {"uri": "8217521780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:19:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:19:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:19:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/obituaries/2024/07/09/joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys/", "title": "Joe Bonsall, tenor in Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "In September, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Mr. Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS.\n\nMr. Bonsall sang with the gospel group the Keystones before joining the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973. He saw the band through its golden period in the 1980s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\"\n\n\"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nDuring his five decades with the Oak Ridge Boys, Mr. Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry. He was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015 as a member of the Oak Ridge Boys.\n\n\"He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage,\" Kyle Young, chief executive of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, said in a statement. \"His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off.\"\n\nJoseph Sloan Bonsall Jr. was born in Philadelphia on May 18, 1948. As a younger man, he and his sister formed their own gospel group, the Faith Four.\n\nSurvivors include his wife, Mary Ann; two daughters; a sister; two grandchildren; and two great-grandsons.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, He was 76.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys announced Bonsall's death in a statement on their website: \"As a 50-year member of the American music group the Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\"\n\nThe statement also noted that Bonsai was a prolific author, writing 11 books, including his recent memoir, I See Myself, which was released last year. He loved to read,\" the statement continued. \"He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nBonsall spent just over 50 years in the Oak Ridge Boys: He joined the group in 1973 and announced his retirement from touring at the beginning of the year because of his ALS diagnosis. {"uri": "8217707716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:33:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:33:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:33:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www2.cbn.com/news/entertainment/oak-ridge-boys-tenor-joe-bonsall-self-proclaimed-light-christ-passes-away", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys Tenor Joe Bonsall, a Self-Proclaimed 'Light for Christ,' Passes Away", "body": "A tenor with the famed Oak Ridge Boys, Joe Bonsall, has died. The Country Hall of Famer was 76.\n\nThe longtime singer died Tuesday from complications due to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Bonsall retired from touring about six months ago, after announcing he had been diagnosed with the aforementioned disorder five years prior, according to The Tennesseean.\n\n\"Bonsall, of Hendersonville, Tennessee, passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis,\" his family said in a statement. \"He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall, Sr., and Lillie Bonsall.\"\n\nIn addition to being inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame, Bonsall was a member of the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nThe late singer also has a memoir, I See Myself, slated for release in November.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing,\" the family's statement continued. \"He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nRELATED 'I Love You, Son': Fans Pray for Country Star After Child's Sudden Death\n\nBonsall was over the years very open and comfortable talking about his faith in Jesus.\n\nIn a 2015 interview with Bible Gateway, the country singer-songwriter said he was at ease talking openly about his Christian beliefs.\n\n\"I have never found it difficult to be a light for Christ,\" he said. \"I don't think it's any more difficult than doing anything else with your life. There are always temptations and Satan is everywhere. The battle between doing what is right or slipping away is everyone's personal decision, no matter what their vocation.\"\n\nAs for his salvation, Bonsall said it was Christian kids who lived near him growing up as well as his mother who led him to trusting in Jesus as his savior.\n\n\"I was heavily influenced by Christian kids in my neighborhood in Philadelphia that never gave up on me,\" he reflected. \"But mostly ... it was my mother who taught me about Jesus and the Bible.\"\n\nNews of Bonsall's passing comes on the heels of the announcement that William \"Rusty\" Golden, the son of Love, Reba\"\n\nPer a press release, Bonsall died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) at age 76. A funeral will not be held for him per his request, but donations can be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nOn Tuesday, fellow country singer Blake Shelton -- who collaborated with The Oak Ridge Boys in 2016 -- also paid tribute to Bonsall on X.\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsalls passing. I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nRelated: Joe Bonsall, Longtime Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dies of ALS Complications at 76\n\nIn January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring with The Oak Ridge Boys. At the time, he told PEOPLE he was taking a step back to prioritize his health amid a years-long battle, though he kept his exact diagnosis private at the time.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe musician added, \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nMeanwhile, in September, The Oak Ridge Boys announced a celebratory farewell tour to commemorate their 50th anniversary.\n\nRelated: The Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall Is Retiring from Touring Due to Neuromuscular Disorder: 'I Will Never Forget' (Exclusive)\n\n\"We are doing a farewell tour because we owe it to our fans to say goodbye,\" William Lee Golden said in a press release. \"They have always been there for us through the good times and the bad. I will always be thankful to every person who came out to a show, bought a T-shirt, played our music, and overall, loved us enough to spend their hard-earned money whenever they could. This tour is for you!\"\n\nAt the time, Bonsall told PEOPLE, \"You could have never convinced that 25-year-old Joe Bonsall in 1973 that in 50 years the four of us would still be singing together and still loving every second of it.\"\n\n\"Our mantra has always been LET'S SING... it still is!\" he concluded. \"We have had our share of challenges over all these decades, but we have always {"uri": "8217607652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:45:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:45:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:45:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://americansongwriter.com/the-oak-ridge-boys-and-joe-bonsalls-6-most-heartwarming-moments-in-recent-years/", "title": "The Oak Ridge Boys and Joe Bonsall's 6 Most Heartwarming Moments in Recent Years", "body": "The country music world and its fans suffered a staggering loss Tuesday morning when The Oak Ridge Boys' vivacious, jubilant tenor Joe Bonsall lost his battle with ALS.\n\nBonsall joined The Oak Ridge Boys in 1973, and the group landed its first No. 1 hit, \"Y'all Come Back Saloon,\" in 1977. The group went on to earn 26 Top-10 country hits, of which 17 went No. 1.\n\nThe vocal group's most enduring songs include \"Elvira,\" \"I'll Be True to You,\" \"Thank God for Kids,\" \"American Made,\" \"Bobbie Sue,\" \"Fancy Free\" and so many more.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys were inducted into the Grand Ole Opry in 2011 and the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015.\n\nHere's a look at some of the Oak Ridge Boys' most heartwarming moments and memorable career highlights with Bonsall front and center in recent years.\n\nVideos by American Songwriter The Grand Ole Opry Inducts The Oak Ridge Boys\n\nIn 2011, the Oak Ridge Boys strolled on stage at the Grand Ole Opry for a performance they thought would be like any other Grand Ole Opry appearance. They finished \"Y'all Come Back Saloon,\" and then Little Jimmy Dickens walked out dressed like William Lee Golden, with a beard hanging to his waist.\n\nBonsall laughed heartily and told Dickens his outfit might have been the funniest thing he's ever seen.\n\nDickens delivered the statement - that come August, they'd be the newest members of the Grand Ole Opry. Allen hugged him, but Bonsall seemed to freeze.\n\n\"I want to let something process for a moment,\" Bonsall said. \"He just said we are the newest members of the Grand Ole Opry. This is a brotherhood and a sisterhood that is unlike any other. We have been around a long time. We have been friends of the Grand Ole Opry for a long time. It's going to take a little while to process. We're about to single 'Elvira' here. So give us a moment. We've been a friend of the Opry for a long time. I've got to admit to you folks, with changing times and all the great young folks in this business who are holding country music high, we've not been singing to you for years.\n\nWe've been singing to you for decades. I kind of thought that Opry thing wasn't going to happen. Thank you.\"\n\nBecoming Members of the Country Music Hall of Fame\n\nIn 2015, Brenda Lee revealed The Oak Ridge Boys would be the next members of the Country Music Hall of Fame. The band's members - Bonsall, Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sturban - lined up behind Brenda Lee as she hosted the press conference announcing them as inductees. When the event was over, Bonsall, always vibrant with an undeniable excitement and zest for life, bent his knees to accommodate Lee's 4'9'' height, opened his arms wide, and she rushed into his embrace for a congratulatory hug.\n\n\"Our children's children's children's children can see that,\" Bonsall said of the group's commemorative marker that hangs in the Country Music Hall of Fame. \"Even when we are gone, we'll still be here.\"\n\nThe night they were inducted into The Country Music Hall of Fame, Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood, Jeff Hanna, and Allen's daughter and her family band Rockland Road sang their hits back to them.\n\n\"This was high school for me,\" Brooks said of the Oak Ridge Boys' music. \"'Y'all Come Back Saloon,' that's that whole record that changed everything. They're also the group that did 'Callin' Baton Rouge' first. It all goes back.\n\n\"'I'll Be True to You' was not a duet,\" Yearwood added. \"But everything the Oak Ridge Boys did was four-part harmony, so it was easy to figure out and make it into a duet.\"\n\nCountry Music Hall of Famer Kenny Rogers inducted the band in the modern era artist category.\n\n\"In a lifetime and in a career of incredible things, this is the most incredible thing that's ever happened to the Oak Ridge Boys,\" Bonsall said. \"We run our group as a family, trying to be honest, like our parents taught us. Treat people right. I really think that's why we're here today.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys Team With Blake Shelton\n\nIn 2016, The Oak Ridge Boys teamed with Blake Shelton for his cut \"Doing It to Country Songs\" from his \"If I'm Honest\" album. At CMA Fest, Shelton took the Oaks everywhere, making sure to expose them to a new generation of country music fans. That week in June, The Oaks went with Shelton to his exhibit opening at The Country Music Hall of Fame and played with him stage with him at the CMT Awards.\n\n\"I tell you, it's going to be epic,\" Bonsall said at the time. \"It's going to be really cool. We're actually stripping,\" he joked.\n\nThen, the band surprised fans at Nissan Stadium when they joined him to sing \"Doing It to Country Songs.\"\n\n\"Only in Nashville, Tenn., do you get something like that, man,\" Shelton told fans. \"That cost me a lot of money. You're welcome. They're very expensive. I have to take a moment now and soak that in. That just happened. Moment of silence, everybody, please, for The Oak Ridge Boys.\"\n\nKept Promise To Sing at George H. W. Bush's Funeral\n\nBefore he died, George H. W. Bush wrote that he wanted the Oak Ridge Boys to sing \"Amazing Grace\" at his funeral. To ensure they could keep that promise, the Oaks spent months traveling with suits and ties so if they got the call that Bush had passed, they could hop on a plane and show up in time.\n\nIt turned out they needed them. Following a show in Spokane, Wash., in 2018, the men boarded an overnight flight with suits in hand to fly to Houston to perform at his funeral.\n\n\"Cheers To You\" Joe Bonsall and The Oak Ridge Boys\n\nIt was the end of June 2020 when up-and-coming country group Essex County was fighting against the pandemic to be seen and heard when, like the rest of the music industry, they'd lost the opportunity to play live. The men, a U.K. brother trio, and their manager devised a plan to release an EP, record videos for the songs and then release the videos on CMT. The project would make them the first act to release a video EP on the network, and the network agreed to play each video in rotation.\n\nThe concept for the trio's \"Cheers To You\" music video was that the group would ask other country music acts to make cameos in the clip or submit videos of themselves toasting with cocktails. The Oak Ridge Boys - already Grand Ole Opry members and Country Music Hall of Famers - agreed to appear in the music video.\n\nEssex County met The Oak Ridge Boys in Hendersonville, Tennessee, where they filmed a television appearance and spent an afternoon filming video footage together. Bonsall and the rest of the Oaks, learned lines to the song and played along with the afternoon of hijinx, even toasting with flower vases when they had nothing else to use.\n\n\"We were so privileged to have made a music video with American legends, The Oak Ridge Boys,\" singer Nate Bass said. \"They were amazing and so kind to us newbies. Joe told us to stay together and keep pushing, and something like the music industry was tough, and we had to be tougher. Thank you, Joe.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys Join Alabama To Play June Jam, the First Since 1997\n\nCountry Music Hall of Famers Alabama are still touring, and in recent years, they reached out to The Oak Ridge Boys to tour with them. That ask extended to June Jam in 2023, the first time Alabama had hosted its iconic festival since 1997. The Oak Ridge Boys wouldn't miss it.\n\nBonsall's health was failing. He had to be helped to the stage and played the show perched on a stool.\n\nDressed in a bright green button-up shirt, jeans, and sneakers, Bonsall anchored his side of the stage, tapping his foot, clapping his nads over his head, and leading the fans with every ounce of energy he gave when he was still able to play standing up.\n\nMore than 11,000 people danced and sang along to \"American Made,\" \"Elvira\" and more. Other than the fact he was seated, Bonsall looked healthy. No one knew it could be the last time they would see him on stage.\n\n(Photo by Jason Kempin/Getty Images)", "source": {"uri": "americansongwriter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "American {"uri": "8217548860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:46:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:46:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:46:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://tasteofcountry.com/oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-dead-dies-legacy/", "title": "OPINION: Joe Bonsall's Legacy in the Oak Ridge Boys Is WAY Bigger Than Just Music", "body": "When I read the news that Oak Ridge Boys singer Joe Bonsall had died on Thursday (July 9), my first thought was sadness at the loss of someone everyone in country music will remember as one of the genuinely bright lights in the business.\n\nMy second thought was, 'Wow ... what a truly irreplaceable loss for that group.'\n\nWhen I say \"irreplaceable,\" I don't necessarily mean musically. Bonsall retired from the Oak Ridge Boys as a touring member in January and was, in fact, replaced by a young singer named Ben James, who's been singing his old parts quite capably during the group's farewell tour.\n\nAny singer can be replaced, but what Joe Bonsall brought to the Oak Ridge Boys was so much more important than any singing part, song or onstage performance. The Country Music Hall of Fame -- which inducted Bonsall alongside the other Oaks in 2015 -- put it best, referring to Bonsall as the group's \"sparkplug\" in an online tribute.\n\nJoe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' biggest cheerleader, unabashed fan, PR guy and relentless promoter, all in one.\n\nI first interviewed Joe Bonsall in 2014 for ToC's partner site, The Boot, and the thing that struck me immediately was his obvious, unbridled and genuine passion and enthusiasm for the group he was in.\n\nRELATED: Country Stars Mourn the Loss of Oak Ridge Boys Singer Joe Bonsall\n\n\"Far from projecting the seen-it-all cynicism of many career musicians, Bonsall speaks as enthusiastically about the new project and his fellow band members as if this were his first album, and it's contagious,\" I wrote. \"It's not hard to imagine that if anyone ever tried to resist the Oak Ridge Boys in their career goals, the irrepressible singer would simply talk them into going along with whatever he wanted with his trademark mix of enthusiasm, charm and wit -- and they wouldn't even realize that it hadn't been their idea all along.\"\n\nIt was clear that Bonsall was not putting on a show when he talked about how the Oaks maintained their longevity:\n\nWell, we're all as different as night is from day. Each guy is an individual, each guy brings a different type of talent and energy to the table, I believe, and we all love each other and respect each other as friends. And as years have gone by, all of that's actually gotten easier. There's no weird egos here, no nothing. It's, 'Let's get on the bus and go sing.'\n\nSee, I've always believed -- and this could be a message to the kids singing today -- that the music business can be as easy or as hard as you wanna make it. I mean, how about this -- let's all get along, let's go get onstage, let's give it everything we've got, let's hug each other's necks and get back on the bus, get the check, shake hands and go to the next town. It can be that easy, you know.\n\nWhen I interviewed Bonsall again for a book project in 2015, he once again spoke of the band and his bandmates in the most glowing terms possible.\n\n\"I gotta tell you, I can't even remember a bad word amongst any of us for years,\" he said. \"And even if there is, it's the kind of thing where maybe you have a disagreement about something, and you get it right out there and you talk about it, talk it through and put it right out there on the table. You don't sit back and harbor anything. You always have to be open to the fact that your brother, your partner, may actually have a better idea than you.\"\n\nForty years into a career at that point, Bonsall turned humorous when asked if the group ever thought about how it would end.\n\n\"I think the end scares us a little bit. We never talk about it,\" he said. \"I think we've been able to plan every aspect of our career except how to end it, so I guess we'll just have to leave that with God.\n\n\"I think God will tell us when there's no more Oak Ridge Boys. It won't be us. We'll probably fall down out there singing somewhere, and then that'll be the end,\" he said with a laugh. \"It'll be settled for us, man. 'Where's Joe?' 'Uh . . . he ain't coming anymore,\" he added with another laugh. \"'God done said he's done.' So I guess that's pretty much how we look at it.\"\n\nTo the surprise of absolutely nobody, Bonsall did keep singing and performing until very nearly the end of his life, even performing seated at some shows in 2023 due to his advancing battle with ALS. And while the Oak Ridge Boys still have concerts on their calendar through December, those shows are bound to be bittersweet for a group that, according to Bonsall, never wanted to see it end.\n\n\"The great thing is that all four Oak Ridge Boys are forward-thinking guys. There's no slowing down in anybody,\" he told ToC. \"There's just no quit in these guys. It's always, 'What do we do next? How do we make things better tomorrow than they are today?' And that's the glory, because it only takes one guy ... I don't think anyone in this group wants to see this legacy end. All these decades, all these miles, all these songs, all this water under all these bridges -- who would want to be the guy to say, 'Let's end it'? Nobody. Not even close.\"", "source": {"uri": "tasteofcountry.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Taste of Country"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sterling_whitaker@tasteofcountry.com", "name": "Sterling Whitaker", He was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder,\" the tenor wrote on X. \"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult.\"\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" he wrote. \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying,\" he added.\n\nThe band, originally founded in 1943 as The Oak Ridge Quartet, has had many members over the years. The foursome that saw the most success consisted of baritone William Lee Golden, tenor Bonsall, bass Richard Sterban and Duane Allen, the lead vocalist, during their heyday in the 70s and 80s.\n\nIn addition to music, Bonsall wrote 11 books, including his latest, a memoir titled, \"I See Myself\" set to be released in November.\n\nRELATED: FDA approves Eli Lilly's Alzheimer's drug that can modestly slow disease\n\nIn lieu of flowers, the band is asking for donations to be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nAccording to the Mayo Clinic, ALS or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is \"a nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. {"uri": "8217432412", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:00:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:00:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:59:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://americansongwriter.com/a-timeline-hardships-tragedies-faced-oak-ridge-boys-2024/", "title": "A Timeline of Hardships and Tragedies Faced by the Oak Ridge Boys in 2024", "body": "2024 has been a year packed with tragedy for the Oak Ridge Boys. It started when Joe Bonsall stepped down from the band due to health issues in January. After that, the floodgates of sorrow seemed to open on the band. Deaths of family members came in quick succession as the sun rose on spring. Most recently, Bonsall passed away earlier today (July 9).\n\nVideos by American Songwriter\n\nAfter announcing their farewell tour and receiving a Tennessee Music Pathways marker at the Grove Theater in Oak Ridge, Tennessee, the group ended 2023 on a high note. Unfortunately, that momentum didn't carry over into the new year. Below is a timeline of the hardships and tragedies the band has faced this year.\n\nJoe Bonsall Says Farewell to the Oak Ridge Boys\n\nJoy Bonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys as a tenor singer in 1973. He was the face and public voice of the group for much of his five-decade tenure. Then, in January, he announced that his health forced him to walk away from the band.\n\n[RELATED: After 50 Years, Joe Bonsall Bids Farewell to The Oak Ridge Boys; Replacement Revealed]\n\nBonsall took to social media on January 3 to announce his departure from the group. \"Many of you know I have been battling the slow onset of a neuromuscular disorder,\" he wrote. \"I am now to a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" he added. \"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nAmyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis took Bonsall's ability to walk. The disorder would later take his life. However, it didn't take away his faith or his light. He thanked those who had held him up in prayer and asked that they continued to do so. Then, he named his replacement. \"There is a young man named Ben James singing for me out there and he needs your love and encouragement,\" he wrote in his statement. \"His sound is different than mine but he brings a ton of talent to the table,\" he added. He concluded the statement with \"God's Got It!\"\n\nDonnie Carr's Mother Passed in March\n\nBonsall's retirement was a hit to the band. However, it would pale in comparison to the next loss they took. In March, longtime guitarist Donnie Guitar Carr's mother, Phyllis Faye Carr, passed away at the age of 88. More than Carr's mother, she was a member of the group's extended family.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys took to social media to mark her passing on March 13. \"Our guitar player for a few decades Donnie Guitar Carr's mom has gone home to be with Jesus,\" they wrote. \"We all loved Mama Carr,\" they added.\n\nEaster Sunday Brings Two Deaths\n\nAs the sun rose on Easter Sunday (March 31), the Oak Ridge Boys lost two cherished members of their extended family. First, Norah Lee Allen, a member of the Grand Ole Opry and longtime wife of Duane Allen passed away after a long illness. The 76-year-old singer left this world at Vanderbilt Hospital surrounded by her family.\n\n[RELATED: Oak Ridge Boys Mourning Two Deaths in 24 Hours on Sad Easter Sunday]\n\nHours later, Richard Sterban's wife, Donna Sterban lost her father.\n\nFormer Oak Ridge Boy William Lee Golden Loses His Son\n\nOn July 2, former Oak Ridge Boys member William Lee Golden took to social media to announce the passing of his son, Rusty. At 65, the younger Golden had made a name for himself as a singer, songwriter, and musician. \"This is the hardest thing ever for a father to have to face. I love my family more than anything... We appreciate your thoughts and prayers for the days ahead. I love you, son,\" Golden shared in a statement.\n\nJoe Bonsall Passes Away\n\nJust days later, on July 9, longtime Oak Ridge Boys member, author, and philanthropist Joe Bonsall passed away. The disorder that led to him stepping away from the group in January continued to progress. He passed away surrounded by his loved ones at the age of 76.\n\nFeatured Image by Jason Kempin/Getty Images", "source": {"uri": "americansongwriter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "American He is a North Carolina Certified Public Accountant with a Bachelor of Business Administration Degree in Accounting from Radford University. He has more than a decade of experience in public accounting and auditing. Reid serves as the Bank's Information Security Officer and will maintain this role in conjunction with his promotion to CFO. He also serves as one of four trustees for Bank of Oak Ridge's Employee Stock Ownership Plan.\n\n\"Kevin has demonstrated exemplary leadership of the Accounting and Information Technology Departments. He has made notable contributions to both areas with respect to risk mitigation, regulatory and financial reporting, and information and cybersecurity controls,\" said Thomas W. Wayne, CEO. \"He is distinctly qualified to serve the Bank as CFO, and we are excited for the diverse skillset and experience he will bring to the role.\"\n\nWayne has served as the Bank's CFO since the Bank founding in 2000 until present, along with serving as President since 2016 and CEO since 2019. Following Reid's promotion, Wayne will continue to lead the Bank in his present role as CEO and as a member of the Bank and Company's Board of Directors.\n\n\"As our Bank continues to grow, it is time for my role to evolve. {"uri": "2024-07-416751598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:54:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.iheart.com/content/2024-07-09-joe-bonsalls-loss-mourned-in-tributes-my-heart-is-heavy/", "title": "The Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall's Loss Mourned In Tributes: 'My Heart Is Heavy'", "body": "Country artists, organizations and fans grieved the loss of Joe Bonsall in heartfelt tributes on Tuesday (July 9). The longtime member of The Oak Ridge Boys, of Hendersonville, Tennessee, died after experiencing complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He was 76.\n\nBonsall was born in May 1948 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He died on Tuesday morning, per a statement shared on his website and by The Oak Ridge Boys. Bonsall is survived by his wife of more than four decades, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, great grandsons Chance and Grey, and sister Nancy, the statement reads, adding that the family requests privacy at this time.\n\nSara Evans was one of many country artists and fans to pay tribute to Bonsall, writing on her Instagram story: \"So sad to hear of Joe Bonsall passing. My prayers today are for his family and loved ones. I love The Oak Ridge Boys music!\"\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsalls passing,\" Blake Shelton wrote in a post on X, formerly Twitter. \"I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met. My thoughts and prayers are with his family and his [Oak Ridge Boys] brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nEddie Montgomery, part of the duo Montgomery Gentry, wrote in his own post (and went on to share a belated birthday tribute to late country artist Toby Keith): \"OMG!!!! I can't beleave we lost one of the greats as a singer entertainer and a person joe bonsall !! Man growing up listening to the oaks !! Love all them guys the lord needs him in choir !!!! Brother go rest easy !!!!\"\n\nLate singer and musician Charlie Daniels' family said they're \"sad to hear of the passing of one of country & Gospel music's great voices and just an all-around great guy, [Joe Bonsall] from The [Oak Ridge Boys]. I didn't know him well, but he & Dad were friends and spoke frequently. I did have the pleasure of Joe giving me a shout-out from the stage when I was at the [Grand Ole Opry] representing the [MTSU Daniels Center] on military appreciation nights a couple of times. Rest in paradise, & tell a certain fiddle player we love and miss him.\"\n\n\"My heart is heavy this morning after hearing that my friend [Oak Ridge Boys] tenor [Joe Bonsall] has passed away at the age of 76,\" Travis Tritt wrote. He later shared a video from one of Bonsall's final performances with The Oak Ridge Boys before leaving the group because of health concerns. \"Joe had amazing talent and a wonderful personality and he will be missed terribly by everyone who knew him. Joe is with our Lord Jesus now and that brings me some comfort. My heartfelt condolences go out to Joe's wife, Mary Ann, his children and all his extended family. RIP.\"", "source": {"uri": "iheart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "iHeartRadio"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kelly_fisher@iheart.com", "name": "Kelly Fisher", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "8217283188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:04:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:04:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:03:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.ccmmagazine.com/news/the-oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-passes-away-at-76/", "title": "The Oak Ridge Boys' Joe Bonsall Passes Away at 76 | CCM Magazine", "body": "Hendersonville, Tennessee - July 9, 2024\n\nJoe Bonsall, a longtime and cherished member of The Oak Ridge Boys, passed away this morning due to complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). He was 76 years old.\n\nJoseph S. Bonsall, known to many as Joe, was a resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Mary Ann; daughters, Jennifer and Sabrina; granddaughter, Breanne; grandson, Luke; two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey; and his sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents, Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nJoe Bonsall's legacy in music is monumental. As a cherished member of The Oak Ridge Boys, he contributed to their enduring success and influence in country music. Joe was also a distinguished member of the Grand Ole Opry, the Country Music Hall of Fame, the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nIn addition to his musical achievements, Joe was a prolific author, having written 11 books. His latest work, a memoir titled I See Myself, is set to be released this November. Joe's passions extended beyond music and writing; he loved singing, reading, playing the banjo, and working on his farm. A devoted Philadelphia Phillies fan, Joe cherished these simple joys. However, his greatest devotion was to his faith in Jesus and his love for his family.", "source": {"uri": "ccmmagazine.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CCM Magazine"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8219321746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:07:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:07:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:06:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://people.com/reba-mcentire-will-miss-joe-bonsall-smiling-face-after-death-of-oak-ridge-boys-member-8676103", "title": "Reba McEntire Says She'll Miss Late Joe Bonsall's 'Smiling Face' After Death of Oak Ridge Boys Member", "body": "One day after The Oak Ridge Boys member's death on Tuesday, July 9, McEntire paid tribute to Bonsall with a sweet post on X.\n\n\"Joe, you were a terrific entertainer, singer, and a wonderful friend! I'll sure miss your smiling face and your bubbly personality,\" she wrote alongside a smiling photo with Bonsall.\n\nShe continued, \"I can't wait to see you again. Love, Reba\"\n\nPer a press release, Bonsall died from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) at age 76. A funeral will not be held for him per his request, but donations can be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nOn Tuesday, fellow country singer Blake Shelton -- who collaborated with The Oak Ridge Boys in 2016 -- also paid tribute to Bonsall on X.\n\n\"I'm heartbroken to hear of my friend Joe Bonsalls passing. I've NEVER seen Joe when he wasn't smiling and completely full of life. He absolutely loved singing like no one I ever met,\" he wrote. \"My thoughts and prayers are with his family and his @oakridgeboys brothers. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nIn January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring with The Oak Ridge Boys. At the time, he told PEOPLE he was taking a step back to prioritize his health amid a years-long battle, though he kept his exact diagnosis private at the time.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over four years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nThe musician added, \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nMeanwhile, in September, The Oak Ridge Boys announced a celebratory farewell tour to commemorate their 50th anniversary.\n\n\"We are doing a farewell tour because we owe it to our fans to say goodbye,\" William Lee Golden said in a press release. \"They have always been there for us through the good times and the bad. I will always be thankful to every person who came out to a show, bought a T-shirt, played our music, and overall, loved us enough to spend their hard-earned money whenever they could. This tour is for you!\"\n\nAt the time, Bonsall told PEOPLE, \"You could have never convinced that 25-year-old Joe Bonsall in 1973 that in 50 years the four of us would still be singing together and still loving every second of it.\"\n\n\"Our mantra has always been LET'S SING... it still is!\" he concluded. \"We have had our share of challenges over all these decades, but we have always {"uri": "8217752969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:30:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:30:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:29:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.jubileecast.com/articles/31441/20240709/joe-bonsall-long-time-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76.htm", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Long Time Member of the Oak Ridge Boys, Dead at 76", "body": "Joseph S. Bonsall (76) of Hendersonville, Tennessee passed on to Glory on July 9, 2024, from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. He leaves behind his precious wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAs a 50-year member of the American music group The Oak Ridge Boys, Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame.\n\nJoseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November. Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first-and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\n\nAt the request of Joe, there will be no funeral. He was 76.\n\nOn January 3, 2024, Joe, born Joseph S. Bonsall Jr., announced his retirement from The Oak Ridge Boys and their Farewell Tour due to increasing health issues and immobility.\n\n\"Many of you know I have been battling a slow onset (over 4 years now) of a neuromuscular disorder. I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Joe shared in a statement on social platform X.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" he continued. \"I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys' five-decade career has spawned hits such as \"Elvira,\" \"Leaving Louisiana in the Broad Daylight,\" \"Bobbie Sue\" and \"American Made.\"\n\nThe group, comprising Joe, Duane Allen, William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban, is also a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame, the Grand Ole Opry and other esteemed institutions.\n\nJoe is survived by his wife Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy.\n\nThe family is requesting privacy at this time.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024, ABC Audio. {"uri": "8217593935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:30:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:30:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:30:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://ew.com/joe-bonsall-dead-longtime-oak-ridge-boys-member-was-76-8675372", "title": "Joe Bonsall, longtime member of Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "Emlyn Travis is a news writer at Entertainment Weekly with over five years of experience covering the latest in entertainment. A proud Kingston University alum, Emlyn has written about music, fandom, film, television, and awards for multiple outlets including MTV News, Teen Vogue, Bustle, BuzzFeed, Paper Magazine, Dazed, and NME. She joined EW in August 2022.\n\nJoe Bonsall, an author and longtime member of The Oak Ridge Boys for over 50 years, has died. He was 76.\n\nThe tenor singer died July 9 due to complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease, according to a press release shared with Entertainment Weekly.\n\nA funeral will not be held for Bonsall per his request, but donations can be made out to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nSign up for Entertainment Weekly's free daily newsletter to get breaking TV news, exclusive first looks, recaps, reviews, interviews with your favorite stars, and more.\n\nBonsall's death comes less than seven months after he announced on social media that he would be retiring from touring with the vocal quartet due to a \"neuromuscular disorder\" that he'd been battling privately for over four years.\n\n\"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" he said at the time. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all.\"\n\nBorn in Philadelphia in 1948, Joseph S. Bonsall first began singing when he was four years old and later \"fell in love with Southern Gospel music harmony\" as a teenager, per the group's website. He joined the Oak Ridge Boys in October 1973 and would go on to perform the Southern Gospel group's biggest hits over the following decades -- including 1981's \"Elvira,\" 1982's \"Bobbie Sue,\" and 1983's \"American Made\" -- alongside bandmates Duane Allen, William Lee Golden, and Richard Sterban.\n\nThe long-running band, who announced their farewell tour last September, have been inducted into the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the Country Music Hall of Fame over the years. Bonsall, who was a member of the Grand Ole Opry, was also inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame in 1994.\n\nIn addition to his contributions to music, Bonsall was also a prolific author. He penned 11 books including his upcoming memoir I See Myself, which is set to hit bookshelves in November.\n\nThe vocalist's passing is the latest tragedy for the band to occur this year. On July 4, it was announced that William \"Rusty\" Golden, son of William Lee Golden, had died at 65. \"This is the hardest thing ever for a father to have to face,\" his father said in a statement to EW at the time. \"I love my family more than anything. Rusty was a great musician, a talented songwriter, and a wonderful son. We appreciate your thoughts and prayers for the days ahead. I love you, son.\"\n\nOn Easter, the band also announced that Duane Allen's wife, singer Norah Lee Allen, had died at 76. In a second social media post, the band shared that Sterban's wife, Donna, had also lost her father that same day.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. {"uri": "8217753048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:30:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:30:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:29:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.thewestonforum.com/suffered-from-als-for-years-american-singer-joe-bonsall-dies-at-76/", "title": "Suffered from ALS for years: American singer Joe Bonsall dies at 76", "body": "Die US-amerikanische Country- und Gospel-Ikone Joe Bonsall ist tot. As his old band The Oak Ridge Boys announced in a detailed statement,Bonsall died July 9 of complications from ALS in Hendersonville, Tennessee. He was 76. Bonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, two daughters, two grandchildren and great-grandchildren.\n\nAs also reported by American media, Bonsall has been suffering from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, an incurable degenerative disease of the motor neuron system, for about four years. In January 2024, Joe Bonsall announced that he would have to cancel his band's planned farewell tour due to his health condition. He was replaced by Ben James, but is still considered an official member of the band. In addition to his musical career, Bonsall is also an author and has written a total of eleven books, including his memoir \"I See Myself\" which will be published in November.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys, a vocal quartet that has enjoyed success for decades, were formed in the 1940s and initially performed exclusively gospel music. With the addition of Joe Bonsall in 1973, the group also expanded its influence on country and pop music. In December 2018, the Philadelphia-born Bonsall and his band also performed at the state funeral of former U.S. President George H.W. It will take place at the Oak Ridge Campus of Roane State Community College in Room 107 in the Goff Building.\n\nThe Roane County forum is two days later, starting at 7 p.m. Thursday, July 11. It will take place at the Oak Ridge Campus of Roane State Community College, also in Room 107 in the Goff Building.\n\nCandidates without opposition will be introduced, a press release said.\n\nAll candidates with opposition will be introduced. Then, they will be given an opportunity to make an opening statement, and they will be given equal opportunities to answer randomly selected questions from the audience, the press release said. The forum will end with a closing statement from each candidate.\n\nThere will be an opportunity for the public to meet and greet the candidates after the forum, the press release said.\n\nThe League of Women Voters of Oak Ridge is a nonpartisan political organization for men and women, the press release said. It encourages informed and active participation in government, works to increase understanding of major public policy issues, and influences public policy through education and advocacy.\n\nMore information will be added as it becomes available.\n\nMany news stories on Oak Ridge Today are free, brought to you by Oak Ridge Today with help from our advertisers, contributors, and subscribers. {"uri": "8217701991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:27:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:27:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/entertainment/joe-bonsall-50-year-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76-post-5682839", "title": "Joe Bonsall, 50-Year Member of The Oak Ridge Boys, Dead at 76", "body": "Joe Bonsall, a 50-year member of the Oak Ridge Boys, died at home on Tuesday at age 76, in Hendersonville, Tennessee, from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) complications.\n\n\"I don't think they anticipated the end being quite so near because he was still calling and texting people as of last week,\" said Mr. Bonsall's publicist, Jeremy Westby.\n\nMr. Bonsall had announced his ALS diagnosis on X at the time of retirement.\n\nHe had been battling a slow onset since 2020.\n\n\"I am now to a point that walking is impossible so I have basically retired from the road,\" Mr. Bonsall wrote. \"It has just gotten too difficult. It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys band crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nThe band's greatest hits include \"You're The One\" and \"Dream On.\"\n\nBen James, 28, of Hickory, North Carolina, was introduced as Mr. Bonsall's replacement in the Oak Ridge Boys' Farewell Tour on Dec. 30, 2023.\n\nMr. James told The Epoch Times that it's impossible to fill Mr. Bonsall's shoes.\n\n\"Everybody's got their own pair of shoes and Joe's cannot be replaced,\" he said. \"He had that specific sound that only a kid from Philly who grew up the way he did could have. You could hear it in his vocals and it's just amazing.\"\n\n\"Joe was one of a kind,\" Mr. Westby, who had been Mr. Bonsall's media representative since 2009, told The Epoch Times. \"He was definitely the jokester of the group ... always bright, always smiling, and encouraging.\"\n\n\"He was super optimistic during that timeframe,\" Mr. Westby said. \"His feet were no longer working the way he wanted them to and then it was his legs but he always stayed positive. He always stayed optimistic and always pointed to the Lord and pointed to God as far as his comfort and his guide.\"\n\nIn addition to being a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame, Mr. Bonsall was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, and the Vocal Group Hall of Fame.\n\nThe Epoch Times reached out to the leader of The Oak Ridge Boys, Duane Alle, for comment but did not receive a response before publishing.\n\nMr. Bonsall was also the author of 11 books, including his latest, a memoir titled \"I See Myself,\" which will be released in November.\n\n\"He wrote his own obituary,\" Mr. Westby added. \"That was his wish. The only thing we were allowed to change was grammar and punctuation.\"\n\nMr. Bonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great-grandsons, Chance, and Grey, and a sister, Nancy.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217394849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:27:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:27:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:27:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/life-entertainment/joe-bonsall-member-of-the-oak-ridge-boys-dead-at-76/article_c05bc1e0-3e0d-11ef-b835-a311f88a0c46.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, member of The Oak Ridge Boys, dead at 76", "body": "Eloise Marie Valadez\n\nCelebrated tenor Joseph S. Bonsall, longtime member of The Oak Ridge Boys, died July 9 from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. Bonsall was 76. News of the singer's death was released by 2911 Media.\n\nBonsall leaves behind his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He is preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nThe singer was a member of The Oak Ridge Boys for 50 years. The award-winning group annually played Merrillville's former Star Plaza Theatre since its beginnings as the Holiday Star Theatre in the '70s. The Oak Ridge Boys, who regularly performed New Year's shows there and later Christmas shows, performed for the first time at the theater on Dec. 21, 1979. They hold the distinction of being the musical act to have performed at the theater the most. The group's concerts there totaled more than 100.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nBack in 2017, the year the Star Plaza Theatre closed, Bonsall said \"Every year we play there...The people there have become our friends and our family. It's like a homecoming for us.\"\n\nBonsall has written 11 books. His latest, which is a memoir titled \"I See Myself,\" will be released in November.\n\nAt the request of Bonsall, no funeral will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0 * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.
