{"uri": "8218166917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:58:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:58:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:57:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/joe-bonsall-tenor-for-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies-at-age-76/article_580886f2-c093-5446-94a3-90829aca8ef0.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, tenor for the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at age 76", "body": "MARIA SHERMAN AND KAITLYN HUAMANI\n\nAssociated Press\n\nJoe Bonsall, Grammy award winner and celebrated tenor of the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, died Tuesday. He was 76.\n\nBonsall died from complications of the neuromuscular disorder Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, according to a statement from representatives of his family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write,\" the statement read. \"He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say 8-year-old boy dies after Wednesday night crash on I-74 Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop LaSalle County man dies in illegal fireworks incident Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Flick Fact: The $800M ex-farm girl from Stanford and Olympia High? McLean County man detained on cocaine sales charges Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Behind the Pritzker administration's quest to signal Illinois is 'open for business' Funerals pending for July 4 Funerals pending for July 5 Illinois State basketball turns to Lieb, Walker for inside production\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. Ben James, who has performed with Doyle Lawson and Dailey & Vincent, was announced as his replacement.\n\n\"I am now at a point where walking is impossible, so I have basically retired from the road. It has just gotten too difficult,\" Bonsall said at the time of his retirement. \"It has been a great 50 years, and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew, and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all. I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer, I thank you and ask for you to keep on praying.\"\n\nIn June 2022, Bonsall shared on X, formerly Twitter, that he \"could have easily died\" after suffering pulmonary embolisms.\n\nHis memoir, \"I See Myself,\" will be released posthumously in November. It is his 11th book, a collection which includes the four-part children's series, \"The Molly Books.\"\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9718643", "eventUri": "eng-9718643", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-04", "textStart": 1937, "textEnd": {"uri": "8217410599", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:40:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:40:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:40:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/entertainment/flashback-joe-bonsall-oak-ridge-boys-country-music-remembrance/article_49a3d83c-9fec-5625-9c39-40375094e1dc.html", "title": "FLASHBACK STORY: Oak Ridge Boys Joe Bonsall talks about his book", "body": "Joe Bonsall, above left, wrote a book that inspired one of fans' favorite Oak Ridge Boys numbers. He sings it nightly performing with William Lee Golden, Duane Allen and Richard Sterban.\n\nBruce R. Miller Journal staff writer\n\nEditor's Note: In 2004, Joe Bonsall talked with The Journal about his book. A regular in Sioux City at the Municipal Auditorium, the Tyson Events Center and the Orpheum Theatre, the Oak Ridge Boys were favorites in Siouxland. Bonsall died July 9 from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. Here's the story:\n\nIt's amazing what writing one little book will do.\n\nFollowing the release of \"G.I. Joe and Lillie,\" the story of his parents, Oak Ridge Boy Joe Bonsall has gotten countless letters, e-mails and hugs from veterans thanking him for sharing.\n\nRoutinely, Bonsall says, he'll meet veterans backstage who'll say his book -- and companion song -- have touched them in profound ways. \"Last night in Southern California I had an old Marine who said to me, 'When you sing that song tonight, sing it for both our parents.' He was standing with tears in his eyes and his daughter said, 'There ain't much that gets to this old Marine.' \"\n\nPeople are also reading... Where to go for firework displays in Siouxland Panel looks to release more water from Okoboji lakes without hurting flood-stricken Spencer, Cherokee Belly up to the bar-cade: Warp Zone brings bar and arcade combo to downtown Sioux City Saturday in the Park continues to bring in big name acts without charging admission McCook Lake Association president: 'There's really no compensation' for flood losses McCook Lake residents seek answers for flood recovery REVIEW: Bleachers teach plenty at Saturday in the Park 1 killed, 1 hurt in crash near Lake Park North Sioux City updates residents on flood recovery Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 8, 2024 Ex-Plymouth County deputy to plead guilty of stealing drugs Issues continue to plague Woodbury County jail project, sheriff shares concerns Iowa legislator J.D. Scholten earns win in last-minute start for Sioux City Explorers Body of missing 17-year-old who jumped into Platte River to save girl found, authorities say Saturday in the Park 2024 kicks-off with high spirits\n\nThe book did. It's such an important part of Bonsall's life he could easily fill a second volume with letters from fans. More important? \"Young kids today are writing: 'My husband's in Iraq and I was so inspired by your mom I want to be the kind of wife she was.' It's incredible,\" Bonsall says. And it almost didn't happen.\n\nOnce Bonsall decided he would write about his parents, he didn't know where to start. Then he read through his mother's memoirs and \"that filled in a lot of gaps. They were like a guidepost to me. Overall, writing this book was a happy experience. I was a little boy doing what mommy wanted him to do.\"\n\nThe book came after both parents had died. It details their war and post-war years and emphasizes the love that endured through the worst of times.\n\nThe song, also called \"G.I. Joe and Lillie,\" emerged quickly. \"I wrote the song in its entirety on the back of the bus before our show in Lancaster, Pa.,\" honoring veterans. It got a tremendous reaction and launched the latest phase of Bonsall's life.\n\nNow, he says, there's talk of turning the book and song into a movie. \"If there are 20 steps to that process, there may be four taken,\" he says. \"It would be incredible if it did.\"\n\nBonsall says \"Seabiscuit's\" Chris Cooper could play his father in his later years, a newcomer would have to play him in his teens.\n\nLife as a movie producer, though, is hardly on the singer's radar. He's so thrilled to still be doing more than 170 shows a year he can't ask for anything more.\n\nEven the Grammy nomination the Oaks got this year (for best country group) seems like gravy. \"It meant a lot to us,\" he says. \"To be nominated with Diamond Rio and some of the other young groups was very, very big for us.\"\n\nBonsall figures members of the Grammy organization did it as a lifetime achievement tribute. \"They looked and saw that the Oaks were still pounding away and doing astounding things. They figured, let's honor them with a Grammy nomination. We've seen it with Hollywood...folks who've never won an Oscar get one.\"\n\nWhile the group didn't win the prize (Ricky Skaggs and Kentucky Thunder took it), the nomination did make a statement: The Oak Ridge Boys are alive and well and still \"singing our hearts out.\"\n\nWant to make them mad? Ask about retiring. \"When people come up and confuse us with the Statlers, you can really see us bristle,\" Bonsall says. \"This group doesn't know how to slow down and we don't want to. As long as the guys are blessed with health, our hands are in the cookie jar.\"\n\nWhile Bonsall is busy with his book project, William Lee Golden has found a niche as a painter, Duane Allen has increased his producing profile and Richard Sterban is making a name for himself as a fashion expert. Music is the group's calling card, not its only ability.\n\nCurrently, the four have finished half the tracks on a new album slated for release at the end of summer. It has a bluegrass/gospel/acoustic sound and it features another one of those \"written in a minute\" songs by Bonsall. Called \"The Journey,\" it talks about saying goodbye to friends. \"It's the journey we're all going to have to take\" and it emerged, oddly enough, from looking at a picture of Bonsall's parents.\n\nWhile messing around on a dulcimer-like instrument, Bonsall got a \"cool mountain sound\" in his head that prompted him to think about the people he had lost in the past year. \"I started singing to myself and wrote it right there.\" He played it for the others the next day and it landed on the album.\n\n\"I don't write a lot of songs,\" Bonsall says. \"But when I do they come to me pretty quick.\"\n\nWhere this journey will lead is anyone's guess. But it's a pretty safe bet at least one fan will approve. Former President George Bush is such an Oak nut he asked the group to sing at his 80th birthday celebration in June. \"He's going to jump out of a plane at the Bush library,\" Bonsall reports, \"and we're going to be there.\"\n\nThe group will sing \"This is America\" and, if his son, George W. Bush, asks, the four will go back out on the stump to help his re-election campaign. While the current president hasn't declared the Oak Ridge Boys his favorite group, his father has. \"He's such a fan, he asks for songs like 'Freckles,'\" Bonsall says.\n\nGeorge Sr.'s wife, Barbara, even wrote the foreward to Bonsall's book. \"I laughed and cried when I read 'G.I. Joe and Lillie,'\" Barbara Bush writes. \"It reminded me of when I fell in love with a man in uniform. (It's) a wonderful love story to be cherished by all.\"\n\nBonsall thinks his mother would approve. \"It showed everything she would have wanted to share. I talk about my dad (in it) and I'm proud of him. But it will always be my mother's book. That's why it's dedicated to her,\" he says. \"It's her book. Her story.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nStay up-to-date on what's happening\n\nReceive the latest in local entertainment news in your inbox weekly!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "siouxcityjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sioux City Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Bonsall", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Bonsall"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturday_in_the_Park_(song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Saturday in the Park (song)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Oak_Ridge_Boys", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "The Oak Ridge Boys"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siouxland", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Siouxland"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_City,_Iowa", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sioux City, Iowa"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Sioux City, Iowa"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonsall,_Derbyshire", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bonsall, Derbyshire"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Bonsall, Derbyshire"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCook_Lake", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "McCook Lake"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G.I._Joe", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "G.I. {"uri": "2024-07-417706670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:38:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:38:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:25:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.billboard.com/lists/oak-ridge-boys-top-songs-billboard-hot-country-songs/", "title": "The Oak Ridge Boys' Top 10 Billboard Hot Country Songs Hits", "body": "Carly Pearce, Chris Stapleton & Cody Johnson Add Country Airplay Top 10s, Morgan Wallen Takes Top Two\n\nJoe Bonsall, a member of The Oak Ridge Boys for 50 years, died on July 9 at age 73 from complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).\n\nBonsall joined the act in 1973 after leaving gospel group The Keystones. He last toured with The Oak Ridge Boys last December, before announcing his retirement earlier this year.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys won two Country Music Association Awards: vocal group of the year in 1978 and single of the year in 1981 for \"Elvira\" - the track became their biggest Billboard Hot 100 hit, reaching No. 5. The Academy of Country Music likewise awarded the band top vocal group honors in 1978.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys were inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2015. \"For 50 years, Joe Bonsall was the Oak Ridge Boys' sparkplug,\" Kyle Young, CEO of the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, shared in a statement upon Bonsall's passing. \"He was as exciting a performer as any who ever hit a gospel or country stage. His tenor voice was high and clear, and his jovial spirit always provided a jolt of energy, immediately rousing audiences to come on in and take a load off. He certainly lightened our cares every time he sang.\"\n\nOn Billboard's Hot Country Songs chart, The Oak Ridge Boys first appeared in 1976. They followed with 1977's \"Y'all Come Back Saloon,\" which hit No. 3 that October, granting the act its first of 34 top 10s. \"I'll Be True to You\" led in June 1978, becoming the band's first of 17 chart-toppers, a haul that ran through \"No Matter How High\" in March 1990. The act last hit the top 10 in 1991 with \"Lucky Moon.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys' collection of 17 No. 1s ranks third-best among duos/groups since Hot Country Songs became the genre's all-encompassing singles survey in 1958. Alabama boasts 33 No. 1s and Brooks & Dunn, 20. (George Strait leads all acts with 44.)\n\nOn Top Country Albums, The Oak Ridge Boys have notched three No. 1s among 14 top 10s.\n\nBelow, in celebration of the band's music and Bonsall's key contributions, count down The Oak Ridge Boys' biggest hits on Billboard's Hot Country Songs chart.\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys' 10 Biggest Billboard Hits recap is based on actual performance on Billboard's weekly Hot Country Songs chart. Songs are ranked based on an inverse point system, with weeks at No. 1 earning the greatest value and weeks at lower ranks earning less. {"uri": "8219160190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:40:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:40:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:39:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://americansongwriter.com/3-timeless-oak-ridge-boys-hits-featuring-joe-bonsall-singing-lead/", "title": "3 Timeless Oak Ridge Boys Hits Featuring Joe Bonsall's Lead Vocals", "body": "Joe Bonsall joined the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973 and spent 50 years as the group's tenor vocalist. While he was more than happy to lend his voice to the group's rich harmony, the Philadelphia, Pennsylvania native was no stranger to the spotlight. In fact, he sang lead on some of the band's biggest and most memorable songs.\n\nVideos by American Songwriter\n\nThere's no denying that Bonsall was a major part of the Oaks' sound for the five decades he spent in the band. Without his voice, these three songs may not have gone on to be the classics they are today.\n\n\"Elvira\" -- Joe Bonsall Leads the Oak Ridge Boys' Signature Song\n\nDallas Frazier wrote and originally released \"Elvira\" in 1966. Twelve years later, Rodney Crowell released the song as his debut single. Both Crowell and Frazier saw minor success with the song. However, when Joe Bonsall and the rest of the Oak Ridge Boys recorded it for their 1981 album Fancy Free, it became a huge hit. It was a No. 1 country hit for the group. It also reached No. 5 on the all-genre Billboard Hot 100.\n\n[RELATED: Joe Bonsall Tells the Story Behind The Oak Ridge Boys' Hit Song \"Elvira\"]\n\nBetween Bonsall's lead vocals and Richard Sterban coming in with the unforgettable \"oom pa-pa mow mow\" chorus, it's easy to see how \"Elvira\" became the Oaks' signature song.\n\n\"Bobbie Sue\" -- A Crossover Hit for the Group\n\nWood Newton, Dan Tyler, and Adele Tyler co-wrote the songs that would be the first single and title track from the Oak Ridge Boys' 1982 album. It went on to become the group's sixth No. 1 single. Additionally, it was a crossover hit for the group, landing at No. 12 on the all-genre Billboard Hot 100 chart.\n\n\"Bobbie Sue\" sees Joe Bonsall leading the group in a song about rebellious young love. The song's narrator and it's focus -- Bobbie Sue -- run off together to elope despite her parents' protests. The throwback style of the song makes it feel like something from an earlier era, drawing on the nostalgia of the Oaks' older listeners.\n\n\"American Made\" -- Joe Bonsall and the Oak Ridge Boys' Ode to American Women\n\nBob DiPiero and Pat McManus co-wrote \"American Made\" and the Oak Ridge Boys released it as the lead single and title track from their 1983 album. It went to the top of the Billboard Hot Country Songs Chart for a week. Additionally, a re-imagined version of the song became a jingle for Miller beer.\n\nIn the song, Joe Bonsall takes on the role of the narrator who is disappointed by all of the foreign-made things that he uses in his daily life. However, that all falls by the wayside as he celebrates the fact that the woman he loves is 100% made in the good ol' U. S. of A.\n\nFeatured Image by Jason Kempin/Getty Images", "source": {"uri": "americansongwriter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "American Songwriter"}, "authors": [{"uri": (AP) - William Lee Golden of The Oak Ridge Boys says it's been a week of sadness, because both his bandmate, Joe Bonsall, and his own son Rusty Golden have died. (AP) - Blake Shelton writes on social media he had never seen Joe Bonsall of The Oak Ridge Boys when he was not completely smiling and full of life. Bonsall died yesterday at the age of 76. The collection is called \"The 1974 Live Recordings\" and will sell for about $130 when it's released Sept. 20. There's also a three-album highlights set that will be released on vinyl. {"uri": "8217259195", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:47:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:47:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:47:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://variety.com/2024/music/obituaries-people-news/joe-bonsall-dead-oak-ridge-boys-country-music-vocal-group-elvira-1236063450/", "title": "Joe Bonsall of Country Music's Oak Ridge Boys Dies at 76", "body": "Beck Basks in Bittersweet Majesty With the LA Phil at Hollywood Bowl Symphonic Show: Concert Review 17 hours ago\n\nJoe Bonsall, one of the faces of the leading country music vocal group the Oak Ridge Boys since 1973, died Tuesday at 76. The cause of death was complications of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.\n\nBonsall had announced his retirement from touring with the group in January, citing his illness, as the Oak Ridge Boys continued their farewell tour without him.\n\nThe group was best known by crossover audience for the 1981 smash \"Elvira,\" which not only hit No. 1 on the country chart but landed at No. 5 on the pop chart. The following year, \"Bobbie Sue\" also registered success in pop as well as country. Altogether the band landed 17 No. 1 country songs and 34 that made the top 10.\n\nBonsall was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame along with three of his fellow group members in 2015. The Oak Ridge Boys were also elected into the Gospel Music Hall of Fame in 2000.\n\nThe origins of the Oak Ridge Boys go back to the 1940s, and the group took on that name in the mid-1960s, but the combo was primarily known as a gospel act before Bonsall joined in 1973. Johnny Cash helped them get signed to Columbia Records, but the group didn't find major secular success until a subsequent signing to Dot/ABC and the release of a song called \"Y'all Come Back Saloon\" that went to No. 3 on the country chart in 1977. Subsequent No. 1 songs during that early period of success included \"Trying to Love Two Woman,\" \"I'll Be True to You,\" \"Leaving Louisiana in the Broad Daylight\" and \"(I'm Settin') Fancy Free.\"\n\nBonsall had written 11 books, including a memoir due to be published this November, \"I See Myself.\"\n\nSaid a death notice issued by Bonsall's reps, \"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies. But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\n\nBonsall is survived by his wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy. He was preceded in death by his parents Joseph S. Bonsall Sr. and Lillie Bonsall.\n\nAt his request, no funeral will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center", "source": {"uri": "variety.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8217497644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:57:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:57:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:56:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/07/09/country-gospel-singer-oak-ridge-boys-joe-bonsall-als-death-funeral-obituary/", "title": "Legendary Country Singer Joe Bonsall Dead At 76", "body": "Famous The Oak Ridge Boys singer Joe Bonsall died Tuesday at the age of 76.\n\nThe iconic country/gospel singer is believed to have died as a result of complications from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), according to a statement issued by the band on their official Instagram page. The band went on to cite the star's many talents and accolades as they paid tribute to their friend, and band mate of 50 years.\n\n\"Joe was a member of the Grand Ole Opry and inducted into the Philadelphia Music Hall of Fame, the Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Vocal Group Hall of Fame, and the prestigious Country Music Hall of Fame,\" the band wrote.\n\nThey went on to talk about Bonsall's many talents outside of the music realm, and touched on his deep love for his family.\n\n\"Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November,\" they wrote in their statement.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. He loved to read. He loved to write. He loved to play banjo. He loved working on the farm. And he loved the Philadelphia Phillies,\" they said.\n\n\"But Jesus and his family always came first -- and we will see him again on the Promised Day.\"\n\nThe statement advised fans that there would be no funeral, out of respect for Bonsall's final wishes.\n\n\"In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The ALS Association or to the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center,\" they said.\n\nThe talented star is survived by his \"wife, Mary Ann, daughters Jennifer and Sabrina, granddaughter Breanne, grandson Luke, two great grandsons, Chance and Grey, and a sister, Nancy,\" according to the statement. We all lost a special person today.\"\n\nALS is an incurable neuromuscular disease that affects voluntary muscles in the body.\n\nThe singer told fans about his diagnosis in January 2024, after battling the disease for four years.\n\nJoe had a wife named Mary Ann, two daughters, Jennifer and Sabrina, two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.\n\n\"Joseph is also the author of 11 books including his latest, a memoir entitled I See Myself, which releases in November,\" a release stated from a spokesperson in the Bonsall family.\n\n\"Joe loved to sing. {"uri": "8217818398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "00:59:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T00:59:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T00:58:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://americansongwriter.com/joe-bonsall-tells-the-story-behind-the-oak-ridge-boys-hit-song-elvira/", "title": "Joe Bonsall Tells the Story Behind The Oak Ridge Boys' Hit Song \"Elvira\"", "body": "When Joe Bonsall sang lead on the Oak Ridge Boys' signature hit \"Elvira\" in 1981, it was a bit of a novelty for Bonsall. The Philly native typically ceded lead vocals to bandmate Duane Allen. However, \"Elvira,\" written and first released by Dallas Frazier in the 1960s, became the Oak Ridge Boys' most iconic hit.\n\nVideos by American Songwriter\n\nBonsall passed away on July 9 from complications due to ALS. Along with his family, love of animals, and membership in the Country Music Hall of Fame and Grand Ole Opry, \"Elvira\" is part of his legacy.\n\nThe RIAA certified \"Elvira\" double platinum for 2 million in sales, a milestone that only \"Islands in the Stream\" by Kenny Rogers and Dolly Parton had reached at the time. In 1982, the song won the Oak Ridge Boys a Grammy for Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals.\n\nBonsall remembers being in the recording studio finishing recording the \"Fancy Free\" album when a song plugger arrived and said he'd heard a Texas bar band do a version of Rodney Crowell's \"Elvira\" and thought the song was perfect for The Oaks.\n\nAllen first heard the song when Frazier played it on WSM in 1966 and never forgot it, which he said is how to know a song is truly a hit.\n\nWhen the song plugger suggested it to the group, it wasn't hard to convince them to record it. Although Kenny Rogers & The First Edition, Frazier, and Crowell had each recorded versions of \"Elvira,\" Bonsall told NPR that he wanted to reimagine his performance as something new.\n\n\"I never did it like the old 'Elviras,'\" Bonsall said. \"I kind of did my own take, which, looking back on it, was a good idea.\"\n\nJoe Bonsall Thought the Other Versions of \"Elvira\" Had \"Weird\" Elements\n\nHe said the other versions, including Rogers, presented the song in a \"weird kind of minor key.\"\n\n\"We just put our spin on it and had a lot of fun in the studio,\" Bonsall said.\n\nAllen told The Tennessean the Oaks wanted 'Elvira' to be a summer record for families of four. The group imagined Moms singing the verses, the kids singing the 'giddy up' lyrics, and dads swooping in with Richard Sterban's um-poppa-um-poppa, mow, mow.\n\n\"It's the best planning we ever did,\" Allen said.\n\nBonsall remembered their producer, Ron Chancey, was ready to give the song a go.\n\n\"We get in the studio with the musicians, and we sang through it a couple of times,\" Bonsall said. \"I think we sang through it three times. All I remember about that session was everybody was smiling, everybody was having fun, and it worked out well.\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys didn't know how well it worked out until a couple of months later when they were on a tour of the Pacific Northwest. They told fans they'd been rehearsing new songs and asked if they could share them. When the crowd agreed, the men debuted \"Fancy Free\" and a couple of other songs before they played \"Elvira.\"\n\n\"Holy cow, man,\" Bonsall said. \"The audience acted like we gave him a\n\n(Photo {"uri": "8219353448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:39:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:39:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:38:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/10/arts/music/joe-bonsall-dead.html", "title": "Joe Bonsall, Tenor Voice of the Oak Ridge Boys, Dies at 76", "body": "Bill Friskics-Warren reports on country music from Nashville for The New York Times.\n\nJoe Bonsall, who for more than 50 years was the tenor voice of the Oak Ridge Boys, one of the most popular and enduring vocal groups in the history of country music, died on Tuesday at his home in Hendersonville, Tenn. He was 76.\n\nHis publicist, Jeremy Westby, said the cause was complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the neuromuscular disorder also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. (Mr. Bonsall issued a statement in January saying that he was retiring from touring with the Oak Ridge Boys but would remain a member of the group.)\n\nOriginally a Southern gospel quartet, the Oak Ridge Boys had 17 Billboard No. 1 country singles, as well as 17 more that made the country Top 10, after reinventing themselves as a country act in the early 1970s. The group, which has sold more than 41 million records worldwide, was formed in Oak Ridge, Tenn., in the early 1940s, and disbanded and reformed twice before its lineup stabilized with Mr. Bonsall's arrival in 1973.\n\n\"Elvira\" (1981) and \"Bobbie Sue\" (1982), two of the group's best-known No. 1 hits, featured Mr. Bonsall on lead vocals in place of the regular lead singer, Duane Allen. William Lee Golden and Richard Sterban, who sang baritone and bass, rounded out the four-part harmony quartet during its heyday in the 1970s and '80s.\n\nAmong the group's other No. 1 hits were \"Leaving Louisiana in the Broad Daylight\" (1979), an early Rodney Crowell composition, and \"American Made\" (1983), a wry topical number that showcased Mr. Bonsall's clean, resounding tenor. (\"American Made\" was later used in a television commercial for Miller Beer.)", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Joe is with our Lord Jesus now and that brings me some comfort. My heartfelt condolences go out to Joe's wife, Mary Ann, his children and all his extended family. RIP.\"\n\nLike Blake Shelton, Tritt has shared a stage with Bonsall many times. {"uri": "8217472151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:33:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:33:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:32:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://nationalpost.com/pmn/entertainment-pmn/joe-bonsall-celebrated-tenor-in-the-country-and-gospel-group-the-oak-ridge-boys-dies-at-76", "title": "Joe Bonsall, celebrated tenor in the country and gospel group the Oak Ridge Boys, dies at 76", "body": "If you are a Home delivery print subscriber, unlimited online access is included in your subscription. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nA Philadelphia native and resident of Hendersonville, Tennessee, Bonsall left his gospel group the Keystones in 1973 to join the Oak Ridge Boys, which originally formed in the 1940s. He saw the band through its golden period in the '80s and beyond, which included its signature 1981 song, \"Elvira,\" its 1982 hit \"Bobbie Sue\" and 1983's \"American Made.\" \"Elvira\" marked a massive crossover moment for the group, reaching No. 1 on the country chart and No. 5 on Billboard's all-genre Hot 100.\n\nAmyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, is a disease that damages nerve cells and connections that are necessary to control muscles for movements such as walking, talking and breathing. Most patients die within three to five years of a diagnosis. The illness became known as Lou Gehrig's disease after the star baseball player was diagnosed in 1939.\n\nIn September 2023, the Oak Ridge Boys embarked on a farewell tour that was scheduled to last into 2024. But in January, Bonsall announced his retirement from touring, saying it was too difficult for him physically after a four-year battle with ALS. {"uri": "8217342786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:45:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:45:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:45:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://americansongwriter.com/4-essential-oak-ridge-boys-deep-cuts-that-every-fan-should-know/", "title": "4 Essential Oak Ridge Boys Deep Cuts That Every Fan Should Know", "body": "The Oak Ridge Boys have been together, albeit with a revolving door of former and current members, since the late 1940s. The country-gospel outfit has delivered countless hits through the years, from \"Elvira\" to \"Bobbie Sue\" to \"American Made\". That being said, the band has released over 30 studio albums in the decades since they got together. There are so many underrated songs out there, and picking just a few to recommend isn't easy. But we think you'll love these four Oak Ridge Boys deep cuts!\n\nVideos by American Songwriter 1. \"Don't Break The Code\"\n\nThis 1986 deep cut comes from The Oak Ridge Boys' album Seasons. The harmonies are right, the melody is catchy, and the lyrics are quite relatable. It's surprising that this song wasn't released as a single on the album.\n\n2. \"I Guess It Never Hurts To Hurt Sometimes\"\n\nThe late great Randy VanWarmer wrote this little track for the 1984 album Deliver. It's notably about the death of VanWarmer's father, and it turned into one of The Oak Ridge Boys' best ballads of their career. Joe Bonsall's vocals on this song are notably emotional and passionate.\n\n3. \"Come On In\"\n\nThe Oak Ridge Boys are known for splitting up the lead vocals among most of their hits fairly evenly. However, the 1979 hit song \"Come On In\" features each of the band members' singing abilities beautifully, all in just one track. Nobody does melodies quite like The Oak Ridge Boys!\n\n4. \"Leaving Louisiana In The Broad Daylight\"\n\n\"Leaving Louisiana In The Broad Daylight\" was The Oak Ridge Boys' very last single of the 1970s from their 1979 album The Oak Ridge Boys Have Arrived. The song was originally written by Rodney Crowell and Donivan Cowart, and performed by Emmylou Harris in 1978. However, The Oak Ridge Boys put their own unique spin on it, and it managed to hit no. 1 on the Hot Country Songs chart.\n\nPhoto by Jason Kempin\n\nWhen you purchase through links on our site, we may {"uri": "8217484719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:44:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:44:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:44:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.distractify.com/p/joe-bonsall-cause-of-death", "title": "Oak Ridge Boys Member Joe Bonsall Passed Away at 76", "body": "His cause of death is directly related to his decision to retire from touring performances earlier in the year.\n\nAccording to USA Today, the tenor vocalist passed away from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS. Joe had already retired from touring with the Oak Ridge Boys earlier in the year as a result of the progression of the disease, with bluegrass and gospel performer Ben James taking his place in touring shows. At this time, there are no further details on his passing while his family and friends privately mourn.\n\n\"It has been a great 50 years and I am thankful to all the Oak Ridge Boys, band, crew and staff for the constant love and support shown to me through it all,\" he told The Nashville Tennessean in January. \"I will never forget, and for those of you who have been constantly holding me up in prayer.\"\n\nJoe became part of the Oak Ridge Boys in 1973, holding his position in the group for five decades. Throughout Joe's tenure with the group, they began to focus more on the entertainment than the gospel of the quartet's original messaging, packaging their performances as a more mainstream country act. This helped to skyrocket the group to success, marked by 14 songs hitting the Top 10 Billboard Country charts.\n\nIn addition to music, Joe was also an author, penning 11 books (mostly children's books) and a memoir that's still scheduled to be published in November 2024. In lieu of a funeral, Joe has requested that donations be made to the ALS Association or the Vanderbilt Medical Center ALS and Neuroscience Research Center.", "source": {"uri": "distractify.com", From their first hit single, 1977's \"Y'all Come Back Saloon\" to their version of \"Elvira,\" a 1981 crossover smash, the Oaks' catalog is rich in country music gems. But they also had gospel music in their blood, working heavenly harmonies into secular hits like \"Trying to Love Two Women\" and releasing full albums of gospel material throughout their decades-long career.
